0743496736|5.0|Nineteen Minutes by Jodi Picoult is one of the most incredible, inspiring and thought provoking novels I have ever read. This book has changed how I look at people my own age. This novel takes place in New Hampshire, a small quiet town, where not a lot happens. However, that is until a boy, named Peter, comes to school with four guns, explosives and two bombs. The school breaks out in chaos. Peter is sent to court, charged with eight acounts of 1st degree murder and two acounts of 2nd degree murder. After reading the first two chapters about Peter, you would think of him on an evil person. Yet, Jodi Picoult does an excellent job of giving a deep understanding of who Peter actually is. He is a kind and misunderstood boy.    I extremily enjoyed that each chapter was a different story that revealed something more about each character. In each chapter, my opinion would alter about each character. In the begining of the novel, I thought Peter was a monster, yet after reading how he was treated from the time he was a boy by his classmates in Elementary School, Middle School and High School, I completely understood how Peter felt. Moreover, the only person that ever really understood him ditched him when she wanted to be popular. Peter was always a joke to all of his classmates and never had many friends. He was teased everyday from the first day of kindergarden until March 6, 2007, the day he came to school with guns and bombs. Although, Josi, his first and only true friend, stood up for him constantly, her support stopped in 6th grade when she became popular and forgot all about Peter.    Another quality in this novel that made me want to keep reading is that I loved how relatable all the character are in this book. Any high school student including Peter who was considered a \\"monster.\\" However, I thought Josi was also a very interesting character. When I was reading about Josi's life, I was not sure how I felt about her. She was one of the popular girls with her perfectfriends and perfect boyfiend, who would not dare to hang out with someone like Peter, with fear of hurting her reputation. However, on the inside, she hated her abusive boyfriend, minipulative friends and herself. Now reflecting on it she was an insecure and scared girl who would probably rather hang out with Peter than anyone else. She even knew this about herself but was scared to say those words outloud until it was too late, \\"The rest of us, we're all like Peter. Some of us just do a better job of hiding it. What's the difference between spending your life trying to be invisible, or pretending to be the person you think everyone wants you to be? Either way you're faking.\\" (pg 447) As much as I hated Josi as a character at times, I could not help but feel I have been in her position before. Reading about Peter and Josi in high school made me think how often I have had the same thoughts and wanted to do some of the actions they have done.   This book has touched my heart. One of the most heart thumping, tear jerking moments is when Peter sacrifices the rest of his life for Josi, a girl who would never do anything for him in public because she was too selfish and scared. When Peter went to court, his lawer, Jordan, told Peter he had to tell him everything he remembers about the school shooting in order to help him. Moreover, Peter had told Jordan everything he had done, but he did not tell him he also had help. Josi ended up lending a hand in the school shooting and Peter never told anyone, \\"Josie realized he was offering her a way out- a deal sealed in blood, a partnership of silence: I won't share your secrets, if you don't share mine. (441)\\" this is one of the most powerful moments in the book. Peter could have had very different results in court if he told this information to Jordan. However, Peter would have done anything for his \\"friend\\" Josi. This book described a deeper meaning of love than I have ever read before. This book can change how you look at anyone. This novel is a must read!

0198326769|2.0|Unfortunately, after reading The Boy in the Striped Pajamas by John Boyne I could not possibly envision myself selecting this book from my shelf anytime in the future. Though this novel sheds some light on the misfortunes of the Holocaust by introducing the life of a regular, everyday family, it was not an enjoyable read. Though this German family living in Berlin may seem normal, there was one twist to these people's lives, and that was their father's career. A mother, a son, and a daughter, followed their father, a Nazi leader during the Holocaust to a new, unwelcoming home. The hardships they faced were unexpected and interesting to read about, yet I found many flaws throughout the novel.  Bruno, the son in this German family, seems to be the youngest, yet the wisest. He forms an incredibly close bond to a young Jewish boy who lies behind the fence that separates society into two. Just outside their new home, lies camp Out-With. Bruno's selfish and snobby sister Gretel, who lived in the bedroom next door, seemed to show little care in the brutal lifestyle of those behind the fence. Being that she was older, she seemed to have known much more about the camp itself than young Bruno. Though Gretel knew so much more, Bruno's lack of knowledge gave him the opportunity to ignore the discrimination that his people inflicted upon Jews. \\"Jews,' said Bruno, testing the word out. He quite liked the way it sounded. `Jews,' he repeated. `All the people over that side of the fence are Jews.\\" (p. 182)   Bruno was unaware of his brave, courageous, and rebellious actions, but in becoming best friends with a Jew, I find him to be the wisest of them all. His weak Mother knew exactly what she was doing when she brought her family behind her husband to their new home. She was obviously against the way the Jews were being treated and the fact that her husband led a majority of it, but she was unable to stand up to him or anyone else around her. It wasn't clear in the novel, but she seemed to have had a relationship with one of the Lieutenants in the home, Lieutenant Kotler. I found this to be nothing but a distraction from the story, for there was not enough information about the relationship for me to have felt an impact. Lastly, is the Father, the reason this novel has come to book stores. His leadership seemed to be his most prized possession. Being a leader in the Nazi revolution, Bruno's father was strict, ignorant, and incredibly distant. There were no bonds between the Father and any character in the book. This brings me to inform readers around the world that The Boy in the Striped Pajamas portrayed an incredibly poor sense of relationships. Not only that, there were very limited views of the characters in the book besides young Bruno and his new friend.   Bruno's friend was a young Jewish boy, same age as he, who lived on the other side of the fence. Shmuel was skinny, tired, and seemed incredibly miserable all the time. The young boy's friendship was an inspiration and quite amazing to read about, but I disliked the fact that Bruno was simply just clueless. If Bruno had known about the discrimination and the reason behind camp Out-With and the large fence yet still loved Shmuel the same way, there would have been a much deeper message with a larger impact on the reader. It seemed incredibly unrealistic that this camp was in his backyard, and he knew so little about it. Being that he was jealous of all the people in the Striped Pajamas, it was obvious he was completely unaware of his life and the lives of others around him. It was his ignorance that allowed him to be so wise.   Bruno eventually takes a large step and crosses the fence, joining the other half of society. The description that the author left us with was vague and pathetic. \\"Instead there were crowds of people sitting together in groups, staring at the ground, looking horribly sad; they all had one thing in common: they were all terribly skinny and their eyes were sunken and they all had shaved heads, which Burno thought must have meant there had been an outbreak of lice there too.\\" (p. 208) The description given left the reader with no new knowledge and no deep feelings of sadness or shame. I grew irritated from this description because it is merely foolish to be in camp Out-With and to assume the reason for each individual's shaved heads was due to lice. There were no strong moments for the reader or for Bruno to feel deep emotions for the people in this situation.    This novel does not give a pleasant, meaningful, or even darkening mood to a reader. I felt very little emotions, connections, and relationships among the characters and between myself and the book. I cannot recommend this to anyone who is looking for a thoughtful and evocative book.

0061537969|5.0|Garth Stein's third novel, \\"The Art of Racing in the Rain\\", is phenomenal on so many levels. Told from the perspective of a wise, old dog, Enzo, the novel is told retrospectively and is brought to a heart-wrenching end that had me on the verge of tears. Enzo tells the story of the life of his owner, Denny Swift, who also happens to be an up-and-coming car racer. As a result of being alone all day while Denny is gone, Enzo gains a lot of knowledge of the outside world just by sitting and watching TV; he gathers knowledge by simply listening as he cannot speak. Enzo is also able to harbor knowledge of racing by watching footage of Denny racing; Enzo constantly connects the art of racing in the rain with the art of being a human, repeating the mantra, \\"That which you manifest is before you\\".  The book tells of a very happy family: Denny, his wife, Eve, and their daughter, Zoe. The book also tells of a very torn family. One night, Enzo realizes something is wrong with Eve, but he cannot do anything about it. Terrible things happen to good people, as Denny, Eve, Enzo and Zoe are thrown into a whirlwind of tragedies. Although the outcomes of many of those tragedies are somewhat predictable, Stein still finds ways to evoke a multitude of emotions from the reader. At points I yearned to be in the book and to fix everything as Enzo, as a dog, could not.    My only complaint is that Enzo's knowledge and behavior gradually appears to be too human. I thoroughly enjoyed reading his musings about being a typical dog (watching crows, coping with loneliness, the lack of an opposable thumb), however I found it very strange when, later in the book, Enzo began philosophizing and making profound connections between car racing and human life. I don't mean to sound doubtful about dogs' intelligence and their ability to be emotionally attached to their owners, but Enzo seems to frequently transcend the boundary between being a dog and being a human. At times it seems as if Garth Stein istalking, not Enzo.    This is a book I would recommend to just about anyone, but especially to dog owners and pet lovers. Don't be repelled by the philosophical musings and the occasional racing lessons. The book explores themes such as rebirth and destiny, as Enzo thinks he will be a human in his next life; Enzo fantasizes about the day he gets to meet his owner and shake his hand, opposable thumbs and voice intact. The novel is full of life lessons that I certainly took a lot away from. One that stuck with me is something Enzo thought when referring to his future life as a human: \\"To live every day as if it had been stolen from death, that is how I would like to live.\\" (pg. 160)
0307272702|5.0|This should be required reading.  I will caution that if you go to a very strict protein only diet, it will cause some people to feel a little sick until you acclimate.

Once you create the easy \\"basics\\", the lessons advance with each project... building on the \\"previous\\" lesson/formula. And with each consecutive lesson... they becomes slightly more changeling.<br /><br />If you don't take the time to \\"make\\" and truly understand each lesson, you will soon find yourself \\"lost\\". So take the time to fully learn each lesson before you move on to the next lesson. Even if that means repeating the lesson... over and over.... until you do understand it completely or see a mistake you have made.<br /><br />For this reason, I find this book an excellent teacher. You can't just jump randomly all over the book. And yes, some lessons are \\"tricky\\". But, wow! Once you finally \\"get-it\\", you see how amazing paper engineering is. And you'll start to get creative ideas of your own.<br />This book pushes you to \\"think\\" and \\"create\\" on your own.<br />If you want templets and every single measurement down to the millimeter, this book is not for you.<br />If you truly want to learn paper engineering, so you can \\"create\\" pop-ups using your own brain and idea's... this book is for you.

B004LOUD80|5.0|LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT (1972) is the film that brought Wes Craven to the movie world, and the movie was a smash hit.  But the film proved so controversial and caused people so much discomfort that theatre owners and projectionists cut each copy of the film to keep audiences from over-reacting.  The plot is absolutely clear from the ads promoting the film:  A young woman is dying in the woods.  What happens next?  LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT is one of the few films that actually tries to express what violent acts not only do to the victims but also the perpetrators.  When the parents of one of the victims find out that their daughter's killers are staying in their house, they exact their own VIOLENT revenge.  Many people hate this film for its depiction of torture and violence, yet Hollywood keeps churning out revenge pics with glowing critical support.  LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT is brutal and difficult to watch, but it doesn't pull its punches, which makes it a brilliant little exploitation flick.

B004G5ZXVQ|5.0|As the 31st reviewer it's going to be hard to find something novel to say, so I'm going to keep this short.  \\"Collapse Into Now\\" is a fine album. For $9.99 you're going to be pushed to find something more enjoyable.  Money well spent, I say.

B004G5ZXVQ|4.0|Hm. This is an intriguing listen. For years R.E.M. fans have been defending the band's various post-Bill Berry missteps by proclaiming them \\"underrated\\", but come on. We all know they were not nearly on the level of the late `80s, early `90s material. Then came Accelerate, a powerful, if somewhat straightforward, musical representation of anger and frustration. And here we are. Now.     I judge music on intentions and how well those intentions were carried out. Collapse Into Now's intent was to show us that a band with 14 albums already under their belt can take their basics and make them new and exciting. For the most part, Collapse Into Now does this. The fun, thumping \\"Discoverer\\" is a great album opener, reminiscent of the kind of \\"These Days\\"  excitement that has been missing for a long time in the R.E.M. catalogue. It gives way to \\"All the Best\\", which is not a great follow-up song and is all too reminiscent of Accelerate, but its message that R.E.M. is trying to prove something (\\"I'll show the kids how to do it fine\\") is crucial to the meaning of the work as a whole. Perhaps it was just misplaced. Then there's \\"Uberlin\\", which is a terrific update of \\"Drive\\" and, though we feel the tiredness of the narrator, the song feels fresh, and that balance can probably be entirely credited to Stipe for his fantastic performance and effective lyrics. \\"Oh My Heart\\" chronicles a man's return to New Orleans after the Hurricane Katrina, and is possibly the most effective piece on the album, giving a shout-out to \\"Houston\\" from Accelerate with the lines \\"The storm didn't kill me/The government changed...\\". The mandolin sound is straight from \\"Losing My Religion\\" but it does not sound hackneyed here; rather, it is haunting and beautiful. \\"It Happened Today\\", if lazy on lyrics, makes up for it in the sheer beauty of the harmonies that make up over half of the song. \\"Every Day is Yours to Win\\" is an odd one, and I think it gets mixed up in itself thematically, but it is a pretty piece of music. \\"Mine Smell Like Honey\\" is refreshing in that Stipe is not afraid to be a little silly like in olden days, but I fear that it is the wrong choice for a lead single. \\"Walk it Back\\" feels like filler but is tolerable, and then comes one of the best: \\"Alligator Aviator Autopilot Antimatter\\". The song's lyrics are whimsical and the riff is catchy to say the least. And I applaud for Peaches for doing a great job without overshadowing Michael Stipe. \\"That Someone is You\\" is a fun one. It's succinct and the lyrics are unpretentious and honest. Then comes \\"Me, Marlon Brando, Marlon Brando and I\\". It is an introspective, surreal head trip, bringing us back to the atmospheric effects of New Adventures in Hi-Fi, and it's a noble attempt, if slightly overbearing. \\"Blue\\" was an excellent choice as an album closer, with its grand poetic rants backed by Patti Smith grumbling out words, her voice wavering and haunting as always, eventually giving way to the \\"Discoverer\\" riff, which is a brilliant idea. The overture connects to the finale, the beginning to the end.       So all in all, what is this album? It is a collection of songs, held together by a theme. The theme is R.E.M. From beginning to end, this album is very R.E.M. It takes from all their different phases and brings it all together. I wouldn't mind if this were their last album in the sense that it does so much justice to the rest of their career. Perfect? No. But damn near.

0671027344|4.0|The Perks of Being A Wallflower by Stephen Chboskky is a captivating novel about adolescent development through social experiences and interactions. The story, written in the form of letters, is narrated by a shy introvert who is intelligent beyond his years. The accurate and rambling voice of a troubled freshman is what makes this book unique and touching. Charlie is a confused boy bordering adulthood who takes the reader through an emotional and dramatic journey of his first year of high school.    Charlie, like most high schoolers, is faced with every day battles: an older sister who thinks he is a pest, parents who don't want him staying out too late, and bullies in the school hallway. But Charlie is also exposed to extreme and intense situations such as violence, rape, and the suicide of his best friend just a year earlier. These exposures, along with the sexual abuse he endured as a kid, cause Charlie worry about things that others would find insignificant and immerse the reader in his life to the point at which we feel like his experiences are happening to us.    Charlie, although he is unaware of it, struggles with the disloyalty of those closest to him. He loved his Aunt Helen very dearly, but her betrayal is ultimately the reason why he can't \\"participate\\" in life. He is \\"very interested and fascinated by how everyone loves each other, but no one really likes each other.\\" Walking through the hallways or sitting alone smoking a cigarette leads Charlie to strange and unsettling realizations.   The idea of submission plays a huge role in Charlie's life, especially when he starts dating a girl named Mary Elizabeth. Mary Elizabeth is infatuated by beauty and is constantly asking Charlie if he thinks she is pretty. Charlie, not knowing any better, completely gives in to Mary Elizabeth's pleas and this eventually leads to their breakup. When Charlie's homosexual friend, Patrick, makes advances at Charlie, Charlie doesn't object. At the end of the story we learn that Aunt Helen's actions made a strong impact on Charlie's character even though he was unaware of this.    With the help of his teacher Bill, who recognizes his potential, and his friends Sam and Patrick, Charlie attempts desperately to figure out what is wrong with him. Every day in Charlie's life is filled with dramatic events and heavy thinking. But Charlie is wise, and he therefore knew when he was going to that \\"unhappy place,\\" or in other words a mental breakdown. When he was feeling happy, he would say things like \\"I don't want to start thinking again. Not like I have this last week. I can't think again. Not ever again.\\" Of course, Charlie wasn't able to stop his thinking and he was usually left feeling even more confused and frustrated.   This is a story that will stick with you long after you've finished reading. Each letter leaves you feeling more intrigued by and sympathetic towards Charlie. The only part of the story I found unsettling was that we never learn whom Charlie is addressing these letters to. All we know is that Charlie is anonymous and he therefore speaks openly and freely to the recipient of the letters. I would definitely recommend this novel to teenagers and readers who don't always need a happy ending. The Perks of Being a Wallflower is quick and easy to read. You will either identify with or be irritated by Charlie, but as a reader you won't be able to detach yourself from this quirky narrator. Chobsky perfectly captures Charlie's heart wrenching tidbits in this novel.

1453682929|4.0|Although The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle consisted of only a small collection of the vast library of short stories that Doyle created surrounding his famous, quirky detective, the reader was still easily able to envelop himself or herself in all of the stories. It certainly does not take a Sherlock Holmes afficionado to quickly grasp the relationships between the main characters, Holmes and his trusty sidekick Dr. Watson, the gloomy setting of nineteenth century London, and the consistent formula in which the pair go about solving the mysteries that they are presented with. His subliminal, cunning approach to the mysteries in front of him leave both his allies and adversaries awestruck. \\"Whenever you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.\\"<br />Sherlock Holmes employs a combination of logic and visceral sensations to come to his conclusions, which almost always make the most intricate crimes and mysteries seem simple and rational. Sir Arthur Conan Doyle teases the reader in all of these stories because the brilliant Detective Sherlock Holmes is always more than one step ahead of the reader. Holmes always keeps you in the dark until the last moment then suddenly unravels the entire mystery in front of your eyes. This consistent structure to the stories of Sherlock Holmes that keeps the audience on their toes sets the pace for a very light read and a rapid-page turner.<br /> The most inspiring of Sherlock Holmes many impressive and eccentric characteristics is his insatiable appetite and unwavering hunger to solve every single crime that he is confronted with. Detective Holmes often expresses his excitement for a mystery right before he begins to hunt for clues by saying \\"The game's afoot,\\". The unique language that is used in all of the dialogue between Sherlock Holmes and his trusty ally Dr. Watson are guaranteed to enchant Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's audience.<br /> Reading these short stories was so pleasurable because even though the author didn't explore the depths of more serious themes, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was able to charm his readers with captivating plots and one of the most original, brilliant characters in all of literature, Detective Sherlock Holmes. These stories can possibly become tiresome because of their analagous traits so reading these stories should be read in measured quantities. Nevertheless, Sherlock Holmes is an undying literary hero who never disappoints. He attacks every mystery with the same relentless vitality and genius and is able to strengthen the minds and evoke admiration in all who are familiar with his work.

B004G5ZXVQ|4.0|\\"This is my time and I am thrilled to be alive\\", sings Stipe on \\"Blue\\", the final track from 2011's \\"Collapse Into Now\\", and he damn well sounds like it here. I am enjoying every second of this album, from the first listen it struck me as something special, something different, something of a revival from what REM have released in the past four or five albums. These are masters at work here, doing what they do best.    2006's \\"Accelerate\\" was a great album, I do however consider it a Peter Buck album, due to the fact that it is his guitar playing that shines throughout it's entire run.    \\"Collapse\\" seems to be Stipe's moment. Don't get me wrong, Peter Buck and Mike Mills are fantastic here, top form, and Peter Buck's return to the Mandolin is here! It's just apparent that Stipe's lyrics and vocals are some of his finest to date on the album. The lyrics are very introspective and he genuinly seems to have a direct connection to what he's saying, the poet side of him is alive and well on \\"Collapse\\".     It's the 1st time I've listened to an album from REM in the last 15 years and thought, now THESE are the guys that wrote \\"Automatic For The People\\".    What I like most about the album is the diversity it contains, the album opens with a couple of rockers that are reminisant of \\"accelerate\\" or \\"Monster\\", then the acoustic guitar comes out and REM pulls some ballads out, that bring to mind \\"Out of Time\\", or \\"AFTP\\", not duplicating though, just reminders that they can still write the masterful heartfelt ballad.     Then there's the final track, which in my opinion is without a doubt the most personal thing Stipe has ever released to the public. His vocals are delivered in spoken word form, as if he were sitting on a stool in a coffee house, pouring out the words that he's written down on paper. He's reflecting on his life and work, relationships and philosophies, showcasing a kind of pride, and optimisim toward the future..what ever it may bring, hoping that he's made those most important to him proud and happy. It's quite touching, plus Patti Smith adds background vocals, making the whole song quite rewarding!    I went back and listened to \\"Accelerate\\" again after quite a few listens of the new one here, and I think that I have gained a new appreciation for it, seems like that album was what they needed to kick themselves back into the limelight, a fast paced guitar driven album to get the fun elements of music back into their system, so that they could write such a meaningful and impiortant album the next time around, and folks that time is here, and it's called \\"Collapse Into Now\\"!    Stands alone as a new classic.

B000M53GM2|5.0|In the winter of 1995, James Bond was finally back.  After a six-year drought involving a lengthy film rights lawsuit, Agent 007's dangerous, post-Cold War world was boldly transformed by director Martin Campbell's $50 million budget into a sexy, thrill-packed spy adventure that re-introduced James Bond to a whole new generation.  After actor Timothy Dalton's quiet exit from the franchise, replacement Pierce Brosnan (formerly known as TV's Remington Steele) would nimbly transcend his previous typecasting as a suave small-screen actor (much like Roger Moore did years before him) by effortlessly assuming Agent 007's license to kill and taking his rightful place in film history as the fifth James Bond.    The plot quickly ignites with the theft of an experimental helicopter in Monte Carlo by the mysterious Russian terrorist group, Janus, which includes flamboyantly vicious Russian assassin-pilot, Xenia Omatopp (Famke Janssen), in order to soon engineer an even greater robbery.  With their brutal theft of a supposedly non-existent device known as Goldeneye, which destroys electronic pulses, Janus is in a position to blackmail countries for potentially billions of dollars or risk having their vast electrical technology rendered non-existent.  Hence, Bond's subsequent investigation leads him to Russia and then to Cuba to finish off a personal vendetta nine years in the making against a renegade ex-00 agent who can anticipate his every stealthy move.    Anchored by excellent supporting performances from Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco, Alan Cumming, Famke Janssen, Joe Don Baker, Samantha Bond, and Judi Dench, plus two terrific cameos by Robbie Coltrane and Minnie Driver, \\"Goldeneye\\" ensures that Brosnan's explosive debut as Agent 007 gives viewers literally the most bang for the buck.  Make no mistake, though: as intended, Pierce Brosnan is the show in \\"Goldeneye.\\"  Even though Dench and Janssen steal some scenes, the new James Bond ably holds his own with them and makes onebelieve he is indeed the legendary spy.  To Brosnan's further credit, his reliability here and over the next three Bonds he made (between 1997 and 2002) prevented the venerable Bond series from descending into the inconsistent, leading man revolving door mentality that the competing \\"Batman\\" franchise suffered from in a span of only eight years.    Overall, I would rank \\"Goldeneye\\" up there absolutely among the best Bond films ever made (somewhere in the Top Five), and most certainly it would prove to be Brosnan's peak Bond flick by far.  What works so well with \\"Goldeneye\\" is that the cast's fresh, invigorating performances seamlessly mesh with the amped-up budget and a sleek, inspired storyline.    Rating (scale 1-10): 9/10 (Suitable for ages 15+ due to its obvious sexual imagery).    P.S.  For nostalgia's sake, you should consider checking out the two-part, 1983 second season premiere of \\"Remington Steele\\" entitled `Steele Away With Me.'  It is really a fun romp foreshadowing Brosnan's destiny.

If you have the interest, you will disect each sentence.  My hat off to Dr. Alexandra Horowitz for writing this book of need. B0000AUHOH|2.0|In 1986, the light-hearted \\"Star IV: The Voyage Home\\" opened to rave reviews and would go on to easily score the franchise's largest financial haul up to date.  As a result, due to a contractual clause involving two-time director (and co-star) Leonard Nimoy, the film's grand success put star William Shatner into the driver's seat for the inevitable sequel.  Three years later, his supposedly epic vision, \\"Star Trek V: The Final Frontier\\" hit theaters during the first mega-movie summer, but quickly sank into oblivion joining Timothy Dalton's last 007 adventure \\"License to Kill,\\" as 1989's biggest sequel disappointments.  The question remains: if Shatner had three years to get it right vs. Nimoy getting maybe 18 months to put together the relatively solid third film, how could Shatner possibly have failed so abysmally given that much extra time and $30 million dollars to play with?    If you are unfamiliar with the plotline, the synopsis for \\"Star Trek V\\" is the following: a failed rescue mission of a trio of Romulan, Klingon, and human diplomats results in the U.S.S. Enterprise's hijacking by a mysterious Vulcan named Sybok for an odyssey to the center of the universe through something called \\"The Great Barrier\\" in search of the mythical planet \\"Sha-Ka-Ree\\" where God supposedly resides.  Along for the ride, Captain Kirk, Spock, and the crew confront their own worst past emotional traumas before discovering that Sha-Ka-Ree is ominously not what was expected.      Years later, Shatner has readily acknowledged that his lukewarm film was torpedoed by ineffective re-writes and, most certainly, shoddy special effects.  After reading in Shatner's memoir, \\"Star Trek Movie Memories,\\" about his original, fire & brimstone-themed premise, I can grasp why his employers considerably muted the storyline's excessively religious overtones.  Apparently, though, the idea of Paramount Studios telling Captain Kirk to start completely over was not an option here.  The end result is, unfortunately, proof enough.  Shatner's commendable desire for a spiritually uplifting theme once again confirms that good intentions don't necessarily translate into good movies (i.e. Christopher Reeve's similarly disappointing 1987 \\"Superman IV\\").  While Shatner and his production team occasionally conjure up a number of fun scenes, the whole film inevitably crumbles beneath the tired Shangri-La premise (and not to mention, some seriously bad science).  In other words, all too often \\"The Final Frontier\\" plays like an expanded retread of various episodes from the original 1966-69 television series.    To sum up, the combination of a weak, recycled script and disappointing FX waste a collection of nice performances while effectively rendering this \\"Star Trek\\" as a voyage boldly going to nowhere for all involved.  Perhaps writer-director Nicholas Meyer (who directed installments II and VI) might have somehow salvaged this debacle, aside from deleting the absurd half-brother gimmick between Spock and Sybok.  Realistically, though, even a screenwriting magician like Meyer would have wisely started from scratch to make it worth anyone's time exploring \\"The Final Frontier.\\"    Rating (scale 1-10): 3.5 / 10 (Suitable for ages 8 and up)    P.S.  As a note of trivia: yes, in his book \\"Star Trek Movie Memories,\\" William Shatner acknowledges that the mystical name of \\"Sha Ka Ree\\" actually originated as a not-so subtle play on Sean Connery's name, as he was the production's first choice for Sybok.

Thwe only flaw is: The next Crossroads needs to add Chaz DePaolo an international blues / rock guitarist, if not, well then catch a Chaz DePaolo show wherever you can, because Chaz Keeps his guitar talking through the whole performance. B004CRR9G0|4.0|This review is for Nausicaa on Bluray, unfortunately I have to specify since amazon has compiled reviews for Warriors of the Wind, Nausicaa on DVD, and also Nausicaa on Bluray all under this Blu Ray release.  Also, this is not a \\"movie review\\" it is a review of the BluRay edition of this film. If this was a movie review it would easily earn five stars since this is one of the greatest works of animation ever created, but has it been treated so with this BluRay release? read on to find out.    I couldnt be more excited upon hearing that Nausicaa as well as some other Studio Ghibli films would be released on Bluray in the United States!  I bought this release day at my local Target, it wasnt easy to find at least for its initial release, it took a few tries at other major retailers to find it. And even when I did it wasnt on the shelves they had to retrieve it from the inventory room, the man told me they only recieved 3 copies.   I was very pleased with the chosen artwork for the front cover, a beautiful hand drawn nausicaa with a very minimalistic brown and blue color palette.   Unfortunately, The packaging has no more surprises up its sleeve.   I was a little bummed with the obvious lack of effort that went into this packaging. When opened you will find only Disney advertising inserted inside. No collectable artwork like the new releases of Totoro, Kiki, and Laputa?  nope, you get no inserts that pertain to the movie, just two ugly discs with the same artwork on the disc as the front cover! lame, could this have been any more lazy? It is great artwork dont get me wrong, but repeated 3 times!  The strange thing is the printing on the DVD is really good with high resolution and DPI. But some lazy designer tried to add some really lame design patterns over the BluRay disc art and the image is low resolution and blurry. Thats right, it looks like it was printed on low setting on a home printer. I was very dissapointed with this.    Now on to the BluRay version of the film.    Video    After watching the bluray version a few times I can honestly say this is the ultimate version of this film, but that still doesnt mean it is as good as it could have been.  This is by far the noisiest bluray film I have ever seen. And by \\"noise\\" I mean digital picture noise. Its really bad. Some scenes look very nice and the Noise level is down, usually on the darker scenes or scenes with a blue tone palette. But some of the day scenes, especially the very beginning of the film and the dust storm look awfull! I would actually prefer watching some of those scenes compressed, and blurred over.  But, on the other hand I realize this is  now a pretty old film, about 27 years old now yikes! So I can give them the benefit of the doubt and understanding that converting this film to bluray isnt always going to be a seamless transition.  But just so im clear, there is far more eye candy in this movie watching it in high def, enough at least to forgive some of the noisy textures. The planes and rigs, as well as some of the scenes from the sea of decay look phenomenal!    sound    The jump to BluRay also doesnt really help with the sound catagory of this film at all. So if you are buying this hoping to watch this film in booming surround sound you wont. Though the english dubs are fairly new recordings the music and sound effects are mostly original and so you are still playing early 1980's recorded music and sound. It still sounds compressed. The quality lacks but the actual musical score is still in my opinion one of the best of Joe Hisaishi.    Extras    The extras are very lacking in this realease, there is nothing new here that isnt on the DVD version of this film. The\\" Enter the lands\\" world of ghibli is nothing special and is essentially just ads for other ghibli films. The only new addition is the trivia game. It will ask various questions about the film and give you a ranking of your knowledge. Its only mildly entertaining the first time through.    overall 4 out of 5    If your a fan of Nausicaa you are still going to want this release, but if your on the fence about upgrading from the DVD  remember your really only spending the extra money for slightly better picture. If you dont own this film at all I would still recommend this version.  I hope with the future ghibli BluRay releases a little bit more care and effort will go into them.    p.s. the menu screen is really lack luster and at least for me its a pain to load! also the sound effect for the buttons is mixed really load, even when the sound is only playing from the tv speakers the title screen music will be really subtle and the buttons go BOP! BOP! BOP! yikes Disney.

0756404738|2.0|***Potential Spoilers***      Jarring -   I'd rate the book higher except descriptions of, and references to, casual sex came across to me as an author's commentary about real-world personal events, not the character's impression of a different culture.    In style, the sex stuff stands out like some other author's inexplicably inserted edits, not matching the lyricism and fairytale feel of the character's telling of a story in an inn.    No relation to story -   The in-story comments along the lines of \\"I do not understand your culture's hangups about casual sex\\" felt like author wish-fullfilment, not story-telling.  Without the casual sex stuff made part of the character's...character, I fear way too much ink was spilled in early onset \\"Old Male SciFi Writer's Syndrome\\", which I describe as, \\"Went here and women threw themselves at me, went there where same damn thing happened and I can't explain why\\"  (i.e. later works of Heinlein and Asimov).  I mean really, if the author is spending his effort writing it and reader's attention is spent on it, it damn well should be made part of the protagonist's characterization, which it isn't.    The in-story excuse \\"I was a young male, do you think I'd say no?\\" just does not fit the character given us.  That sort of attitude is not referred to again or reflected anywhere else.  It felt like the author was trying to after-the-fact excuse his wasting reader's attention.  Instead, that young male self obsession is contradicted without explanation in everything else the character does; for example in the rescue section, which would have been an ideal time to compare/contrast attitudes about casual sex.     For readers, here's my recommendations to make it a more enjoyable story for yourself and more like the excellent first of the series:  a) skip the pages of running about naked with fey and secret super sex tricks that intrude like an excerpt from some Star Trek Ferengi's boasts of home life.  b) skip the teacher's frequent casual sex with student, it disrupts reader suspension of disbelief.   c) skip the scene with the superduper swordswoman, maybe its purpose was to present cultural misunderstandings and missteps that were actually better storytold elsewhere but it felt more like a frat-boy's conquest boasting.    Following the above you won't miss a thing because these scenes are never referred to again and are not part of the story arc.

B001C4CI8U|5.0|I like that this show has a solid story arch even though it's easy to pick up on an episode independently, somewhat like the earlier seasons of X-files.
0756404738|5.0|Well, I have to say that before reading this book, I spent a while looking up all the bad things people had to say about Book 1. Just to cool my Pat fanaticism down. And after reading it, I read all of the bad things people say about this one. All in all, there are those who like NotW but do not like WMF, and those who simply dislike Rothfuss's style. I personnaly love the flowing poetic prose, the strong internal perspective. I believe that this is like The Great Gatsby in that the way the story is told should tell you more about Kvothe, just like the narration of TGG shows Nick's true self(for those who discard Kvothe as a cardboard character at best because the see him exel in everything).  This said, WFM is quite different from NotW, not in the style but in the subject. In the first book, we meet Kvothe. We learn more about him. He settles down at the University. Most of the book is basic character building through the actions and reflection of the character. Little is said about the world and it's peoples, or places.  However, in book two we know Kvothe, and it simply continues his evolution. What you DO see is other places, peoples and characters. People who are not \\"weak characters\\". Kvothe simlply does not know all there is to know about them. The Adem, the Maer, and all of the different places Kvothe travels to, serves to make the world of Kvothe more real, more interesting.  The one worry that haunts the reader throughout the book, however, concerns its slowness. Indeed, Book 2 takes us through Kvothe age 16-17. Kote is 23, has been innkeeper since the age of 22 (about). How on earth will Pat finish up all of this in the 3rd book?    I love the way things are written and described. The fragility of Kvothe's relationship with Denna keeps tension through happy lighthearted scenes. However, it's true that WMF is almost entirely written in the same style as the Trebon adventure in the end of NotW: detailed action. How will Kvothe kill a king, learn about the Amir, become a master of names? While finding the time to squeeze a little trip into the realm of the Fae and pick up Bast on the way? Not to mention his chase for the Chandrian and the apparition of demonlike spiders...  One thing that strongly disappointed me was the passsages skipped over by Kote. My dearest wish would be for Pat to take his time, look into each nook and cranny of Kvothe's life for wonderous stories, and make a 5-book series out of it. The book is not slow by any means, it is intense. Time passes slowly but many things happen. If some of Kvothe's raw emotion from his tough childhood is missed in the second book, he becomes more or a commanding character himself. This is why I give this book 5 stars: Rothfuss polishes his delightfull prose, strengthens his fanstastic universe and shows us Kvothe's growth. To top it all, Kvothe's personality changes more than his powers do.    That said, I am convinced that Pat still has a lot of work to do, still has a way to go before his style truly is polished. This is the greatest thing about this novel: it is delightful, yet I feel that Pat has and will improve. It makes me trust that the author knows what he is doing: Book 3 will be action-packed and maybe the best of the three. I sure hope so.

0385504225|2.0|Not a strong plot.  But entertaining almost in the same way as the film \\"National Treasure\\".  It actually reminded me of that movie a lot.    One thing that bothered me. So unless it turns out that this character decided to use two last names for some weird reason that is explained in the last half of the book, it is a very obvious mistake. If he can make such a simple mistake (or his assistant), what else is completely wrong in this book that seemed to be filled with information that appear incredible.  Perhaps the whole book is a joke on us.    P.S.  It's possible that he did explain why this person has two last names for a name (we don't do this in Japan - yes, I'm Japanese) earlier in the book and I completely missed it.  It's not a kind of book you feel like you want to read every detail.  In fact, I am trying to practice speed reading for the last half!
B001E45XT4|4.0|Headset is great for the price. I use it on a xbox 360. Since headset is a PC gaming headset it has separate mic and earphone jacks, I had to get a xbox controller adapter that had inputs for separate mic and earphone jacks. The adapter works perfectly and with a bit of a modification with an audio splitter for the earphone part, I am able to get both game audio and voice communication at the same time while having clear mic voice communication with the people that I am playing with. The headset has large cushioned ear pieces that completely cover the ears and a padded band that goes over the head making the headset comfortable to wear. I will agree with other reviews that the bass isn't as great as it could be, it does have base but is a deep low base, just not a loud bass. During gaming I can tell from which direction gunfire is coming from (left or right) just not front and back as this is not a surround sound headset but a stereo headset. If you are a PC gamer (or an xbox gamer with the ability to modify connectivity) and are looking for a decent headset, I recommend this headset. If you want a headset for xbox and don't want to modify connections, I would recommend a Turtle Beach headset. Otherwise this is a great headset
B003Y5H542|4.0|Gore Verbinski's animated feature Rango, with voices by Johnny Depp, Ned Beatty and a host of other talented actors, is a hard film to review, mainly because its real target audience is not the one it's being marketed towards. Let me just flat out say it:  this really isn't a kids' animated movie.  Not because there's anything in it that is not suitable for kids - there isn't - but because 95 percent of what really makes it worth seeing is going to go right over most kids' heads.<br /><br />On the surface, the plot is fairly straightforward, at least in the set-up. A terrarium-housed pet chameleon lizard (it's significant after the fact that you never know his real name) ends up stranded in the desert where he is directed to a small town that is on the verge of extinction because of a mysterious water shortage. In his efforts to blend in (he _is_ a chamelon after all), he adopts the name Rango and in quick order suddenly finds himself appointed sheriff and given the mission of finding out what's happened to the town's water.<br /><br />Stylistically, Verbinski was willing to take some real chances with Rango, and anyone who appreciates animation as an art will find a lot to see here. The level of detail and sheer originality is stunning. Rango does not resemble _anything_ I've seen in an animated film before. Though set in the current day, the world of Rango is essentially an Old West town - aptly named Dirt - that's literally drying up, populated by a cast of animal characters who look like they stepped out of any number of classic Westerns. The difference between Rango and your usual animated take on this theme though is that the residents of Dirt are _not_ cute.  In addition to being much closer in look to the real animals they're based on - lizards, tortoises, toads, possums, snakes, prarie dogs and such - they're also grizzled, dusty, sun-bleached and wind-beaten, and in many cases, just downright _ugly_.  Including, or even especially, the good guys.  One suspects that merchandising for Rango will be somewhat problematic.<br /><br />But it says something that everything fits together seamlessly.  The town really looks like an Old West town on the verge of becoming a ghost town, and the characters look like they really do live there.  And again, the level of detail is stunning, from the clothes the characters wear to the characters themselves, the buildings and other structures, the interiors. The four desert-owl mariachi players who sing narration at various points in the film are a case in point.  The level of detail that is taken with their intricately shaded feathers, their embroidered mariachi costumes and their musical instruments - and the way all of these things _move_ when the characters do - is amazing.  This is a movie you could watch again and again just to appreciate how much the artists put into it.<br /><br />I have to mention two characters in particular that really stood out:  the Mayor (marvelously voiced by Ned Beatty), a tortoise modeled directly on John Huston's genial but chilling Noah Cross from the classic film Chinatown, and Rattlesnake Jake (also marvelously voiced by Bill Nighy), absolutely one of the best animated villains ever created.  It's absolutely spell-binding just to watch Jake _move_, a stunning feat of animation. I've never seen an animated character manage to radiate sheer menace on the level that Rattlesnake Jake does.  In thinking about it, I now have to amend my earlier statement somewhat; Rattlesnake Jake could definitely scare some younger children.  But that said, Rango is worth seeing for Rattlesnake Jake alone.<br /><br />My mention of Chinatown brings me to the other prospective audience for Rango:  film buffs. Rango references a truly astonishing number of movies: several classic Westerns (High Noon; The Good, the Bad & the Ugly; The Quick & The Dead, Paint Your Wagon) as one would expect, but also a number of non-Westerns, some fairly recent (Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End, A Bug's Life), some classic (Lawrence of Arabia, Apocalypse Now) and some obscure (Fear & Loathing in Las Vegas). And of course Chinatown, not only for the Mayor character but for a number of scenes (watch for the glasses) and a good deal of the plot. And there's also a key scene that's a nod to a famous actor/director who is still remembered for his association with Westerns and for a certain classic character he created. A good example of the little in-jokes in Rango is what he's carrying around in the back of the golf cart. As I said, most kids are going to miss 95 percent of this stuff. Me, I want to get the DVD just so I can watch it again and pick out all of the references I probably missed the first time around.  It's that kind of movie.<br /><br />About my only real criticism of Rango - other than its being marketed to the wrong audience - is that parts of it are uneven and do tend to drag a bit. I think this is because the parts that do seem to be meant for kids tend not to mesh that well with the rest of the film. The parts that adults will enjoy most will probably be of little interest to kids, and the parts that kids will enjoy most will probably make things drag for adults.<br /><br />But overall, I highly recommend Rango.  It's not your typical animated film, and most kids will probably complain that a lot of it's boring, but for anyone who loves the sheer art of animation or who just loves films that reference all manner of movies from the great to the obscure, this is definitely a film you'll want to see.c (Lawrence of Arabia, Apocalypse Now) and some obscure (Fear & Loathing in Las Vegas). And of course Chinatown, not only for the Mayor character but for a number of scenes (watch for the glasses) and a good deal of the plot. And there's also a key scene that's a nod to a famous actor/director who is still remembered for his association with Westerns and for a certain classic character he created. A good example of the little in-jokes in Rango is what he's carrying around in the back of the golf cart. As I said, most kids are going to miss 95 percent of this stuff. Me, I want to get the DVD just so I can watch it again and pick out all of the references I probably missed the first time around.  It's that kind of movie.    About my only real criticism of Rango - other than its being marketed to the wrong audience - is that parts of it are uneven and do tend to drag a bit. I think this is because the parts that do seem to be meant for kids tend not to mesh that well with the rest of the film. The parts that adults will enjoy most will probably be of little interest to kids, and the parts that kids will enjoy most will probably make things drag for adults.    But overall, I highly recommend Rango.  It's not your typical animated film, and most kids will probably complain that a lot of it's boring, but for anyone who loves the sheer art of animation or who just loves films that reference all manner of movies from the great to the obscure, this is definitely a film you'll want to see.
B002ZG99N6|4.0|Well, there is some talk in this film. There is a tender, albeit somewhat unlikely romance that entails moments of quiet conversation. But for the most part, this is a shoot-`em-up that's set, not in the Wild West, but on the mean streets of Boston. As this crew of bank robbers follow in the presumed tradition of their Charlestown section of Boston and make their living by robbing banks - the bullets fly and the blood spatters. Whatever became of just slipping a note to the teller?    So the violence shown here is rather unlikely. Rarely does even one bank robbery involve so much fire power. It would be rarer yet for a neighborhood to experience a series of bank robberies involving such exchanges of projectiles from heavy artillery. But then this is the movies, and we know we have to be prepared to suspend disbelief.    Actually, the robbery and retribution scenes in \\"The Town\\" have the quality of a violent video game. For whole sections, it's non-stop gun-fire. An adversary will pop-up and be greeted with blasts of bullets. If I had a dollar for every time someone blew someone else's head off - I'd have more than paid for this DVD.    I personally prefer to learn something from movies about bank hold-ups. I want to be in on the planning and process of pulling off such crimes. For example, we're told the robbers in \\"The Town\\" disabled phone communication from one targeted bank by \\"going into the corner junction box.\\" I would have liked more details about just how this was accomplished.     I craved even more minutiae of process. I wanted to know where the robbers bought those eerie masks they used. You'd have thought the police could have traced the robbers merely by finding the supplier of those uniquely frightening wizened nun costumes. You don't see such outfits sold at any Halloween store. They must have been custom-made. Instead of just being in on the kills, I would have liked to follow Ben Affleck and the others as they found a supplier of such masks and accessorized themselves accordingly. That would have been Seinfeld-serious fascinating to me.    But if you are action-oriented, this is the movie for you. It has slick production values, good acting, and the violence, as improbable as it is, is well choreographed and arresting.

0061148512|4.0|[3.6/5.0]    Esther is an extraordinarily gifted girl. Pretty, intelligent, and talented, she has qualities and accomplishments anyone would be proud of, anyone, that is, except her.  This novel is about Esther's (and Plath's) descent into a deep, dark depression that is likened to being trapped in a bell jar that separates her from the rest of humanity and from living a normal, happy life.     Esther is a bright overachiever who made straight A's her whole life and received a full academic scholarship to college. Because of her intelligence and writing ability she is invited, with 11 other girls, to be a guest editor for a popular fashion magazine for a month. The girls are treated lavishly and get to live an opulent lifestyle only a privileged few get to enjoy. Having lived in poverty her whole life, she should be delighted at being elevated to such elegant and lavish living, in the heart of New York City no less, but she is unable to enjoy her new position. In the book Esther says \\"I felt very still and very empty, the way the eye of a tornado must feel, moving dully along in the middle of the surrounding hullabaloo.\\" The hullabaloo being New York City, boisterous and lively, the eye of the tornado is her, empty and lonely.   During her paid internship Esther becomes very critical of herself, which is typical of depressed people. With all of her accomplishments, she acutely notices only her and other people's faults.     This novel is also a commentary on conventional society. Esther wants to be a poet, writer and a professor and feels stifled by the domestic role women are supposed to play during the 1950s. She finds it hypocritical how women are supposed to be pure while men sleep with as many women as they desire.     The first half of the book is sort of fun, but there are signs of her deteriorating mental state. The second half of the book deals almost exclusively with her mental illness and her descent into a dark, frightening world. When she returns to hermundane home after her internship the bell jar quickly descends over her, suffocating and trapping her. Cutting all social ties and future plans, Esther gives in to her overwhelming despair. Experiencing insomnia, an inability to read or write, and extreme depression, she decides suicide is her only option. After numerous suicide attempts Esther ends up in an asylum, which ultimately saves her life and returns her to a state of normalcy.     After a while I started to dislike Esther because she is selfish, cruel, and extraordinarily judgmental; but I guess she perceives the world around her \\"through the distorting lens of a bell jar,\\" and it's very difficult to have a positive view of humanity when you are completely miserable. Only towards the end of the book does she begin to view the world positively and the bell jar is lifted, however temporarily that may be, since in reality Sylvia Plath tragically killed herself at the young age of 30.      The reason I gave this book 3.6 stars is because, although it is well written and poetic, I feel like Plath was holding back her talent. Later, when Plath was talking about her mental illness, shock treatments, and her experience at the asylum, she said they were \\"A time of darkness, despair, disillusion--so black only as the inferno of the human mind can be--symbolic death, and numb shock--then the painful agony of slow rebirth and psychic regeneration.\\" Only very rarely, if at all, do you find any writing as beautiful and complex as that in the book.  I read the above line 4 times to let its beauty and meaning sink in and only a few times in the book did I reread anything because the sentence was deep, aesthetic and complex. Another thing that bothered me was that Plath rarely described her own subjective suffering. The book was mainly just her opinions of other people, descriptions of the environment around her and her superficial reactions to events that occur. I didn't feel like Plath dove deep enough into her agonizing internal suffering.  One thing one must keep in mind is, when writing an autobiography the author is constrained by the events that occur in one's life, where as in a completely fictitious story, like the last book I reviewed, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, the author can create all sorts of interesting and fantastic scenarios, which really bring a story to life. I think that is one of the reasons why I grew bored and impatient with the book at times.

Costumes here are rugged, thread-bare, and often dirty (like they must have been 800 years ago).  Scott's vision here shows English hard living in 1199 (this treatment is useable for teaching the 12th century).  Beware portions of this film reflect the barbarous nature of that age.  There's lots of blood (but little gore) in the various battle scenes.<br /><br />Refreshingly, Director Scott seems intent to tell the story rather than mucking up this great film with foul language and skin.  Among the cursing, there's no profanity.  The lines of good and bad are clearly drawn.  Robin's and Marion's playful romance features no bed scenes or body parts. 0307454541|2.0|I'd like to preface my views with a simple fact:  This book was translated into English. That said...<br /><br />I feel that Larsson's writing style is matter-of-fact, and not in a good way.  It entirely lacks emotion, during scenes where emotions are absolutely necessary. From there, to his time with Felurian, and his time in Ademre, it took me every bit of patience to keep reading. I was so close to giving up. I had no idea what the point of Kvothe spending so much time in these places were. He didn't learn anything about the Chandrian or the Amyr. He just learned how to have sex and how to fight with a sword. Why did Patrick Rothfuss devote almost a third of the book to this nonsense when he could have done it in about 20 pages? It was ridiculous. When Kvothe finally got back to the University, things got interesting again. But that left only 100 pages to talk about all the things I wanted to read this book for. I feel like the third book has to be about twice as long as this one if Rothfuss is going to explain all the mysteries that he has set up so far. He's put too much into these stories, too many webs that he needs to finish in just one book. It will be a miracle if he can pull it off.
159420229X|5.0|Author Joshua Foer leads readers on a fantastic journey into the human mind, which includes the deep recesses of the brain's known and unknown. He leads you into the competitive nature of the geekiest of geekiest mnemonists... culminating in the finals of the U.S. Memory Championship. The author's first visit to the Championship is as a reporter... his second visit is as a participating finalist! That's one hell of a deviation... and the roads that are traveled along the way go in every direction imaginable... just like unlimited memories are magically brought back from all portions of the brain.<br /><br />As Joshua tries to learn everything possible about the training techniques of the \\"mental athletes\\" that attempt to break world records in memory competition... the obvious question arises... can pure hard work and training routines result in a person's mind being able to \\"match-up\\" with what the world terms a \\"savant\\"? During the exploration into these intellectual mysteries the reader will meet sad characters as well as amazing. One person you'll meet is Daniel Tammet, \\"WHOSE BRAIN HAD BEEN ALTERED BY AN EPILEPTIC SEIZURE HE SUFFERED AS A TODDLER.\\" \\"DR. DAROLD TREFFERT, AN EXPERT IN SAVANT SYNDROME, DECLARED HIM ONE OF ONLY FIFTY PEOPLE IN THE WORLD WHO CAN BE CLASSIFIED AS A \\"PRODIGIOUS SAVANT.\\" You'll also be saddened when you get to know \\"EP\\" who has an entire chapter on his heartbreaking plight entitled \\"THE MOST FORGETFUL MAN IN THE WORLD\\". \\"EP's\\" \\"MEMORY EXTENDED BACK ONLY AS FAR AS HIS MOST RECENT THOUGHT. HE HAD ONE OF THE MOST SEVERE CASES OF AMNESIA EVER DOCUMENTED.\\"<br /><br /> Throughout this entire journey the author's literary personality combines a wonderful combination of highly intellectual investigation... with an always present \\"tongue-in-cheek\\" humor... and never leaves the reader dangling with an incomprehensible intellectual term... that he doesn't define for the average layman. There are so many memorization statistics that are (excuse any accidental pun) completely *MIND-BOGGLING*. Such as a relatively unknown Japanese mnemonist named Akira Haraguchi who *MEMORIZED THE FIRST *83,431* DIGITS OF PI! \\"IT TOOK HIM SIXTEEN HOURS AND TWENTY-EIGHT MINUTES TO RECITE THEM.\\" After reading this book you may want to go to London just to talk to a cabbie. \\"BEFORE THEY CAN RECEIVE ACCREDITATION FROM LONDON'S PUBLIC CARRIAGE OFFICE, CABBIES-IN-TRAINING MUST SPEND TWO TO FOUR YEARS MEMORIZING THE LOCATIONS AND TRAFFIC PATTERNS OF ALL 25,000 STREETS IN THE VAST AND VASTLY CONFUSING CITY, AS WELL AS THE LOCATIONS OF 1,400 LANDMARKS.\\" How does that tie in to this story? Part of the author's vast research showed that \\"IN 2000, A NEUROSCIENTIST, ELEANOR MAGUIRE AT UNIVERSITY COLLEGE LONDON BROUGHT SIXTEEN TAXI DRIVERS INTO HER LAB AND EXAMINED THEIR BRAINS IN AN MRI SCANNER, SHE FOUND ONE SURPRISING AND IMPORTANT DIFFERENCE. THE RIGHT POSTERIOR HIPPOCAMPUS, A PART OF THE BRAIN KNOWN TO BE INVOLVED IN SPATIAL NAVIGATION, WAS 7 PERCENT LARGER THAN NORMAL IN THE CABBIES--A SMALL BUT VERY SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCE. MAGUIRE CONCLUDED THAT ALL OF THAT WAY-FINDING AROUND LONDON HAD PHYSICALLY ALTERED THE GROSS STRUCTURE OF THEIR BRAINS.\\" \\"THE BRAIN IS A MUTABLE ORGAN, CAPABLE--WITHIN LIMITS--- OF REORGANIZING ITSELF AND READAPTING TO NEW KINDS OF SENSORY INPUT, A PHENOMENON KNOWN AS NEUROPLASTICITY.\\"<br /><br />I'm sure we all remember the Academy Award winning picture \\"Rain Man\\" starring Dustin Hoffman. Well, Joshua tracked down \\"Kim Peek the prodigious savant born in 1951 who inspired Dustin Hoffman's character. \\"HE HAS ARGUABLY THE BEST MEMORY IN THE WORLD.\\" \\"HE'S NEVER FORGOTTEN ANYTHING, INCLUDING SUPPOSEDLY, EVERY FACT IN THE MORE THAN NINE THOUSAND BOOKS HE HAS READ AT ABOUT TEN SECONDS A PAGE. (EACH EYE SCANS ITS OWN PAGE INDEPENDENTLY.)\\"<br /><br />The characters you meet... and the educational stimuli that are bandied about on this \\"memorable\\" trip are \\"unforgettable. But probably the most amusing sub-plot is watchingthe author, a nice young Jewish man, following a story, (Please note his nice clean-cut-normal looking picture on the book jacket.) who almost unwittingly becomes one of the \\"animals\\" he went to view at the zoo...<br /><br />\\"ALL SERIOUS MNEMONISTS WEAR EARMUFFS. A FEW OF THE MOST SERIOUS COMPETITORS WEAR BLINDERS TO CONSTRICT THEIR FIELD OF VIEW AND SHUT OUT PERIPHERAL DISTRACTIONS.\\"<br /><br />And then the author states: \\"THAT AFTERNOON, I WENT OUT TO THE HARDWARE STORE AND BOUGHT A PAIR OF INDUSTRIAL-GRADE EARMUFFS AND A PAIR OF PLASTIC LABORATORY SAFETY GOGGLES. I SPRAY-PAINTED THEM BLACK AND THEN DRILLED A SMALL EYEHOLE THROUGH EACH LENS. I feel like the filmaker's could have taken more of a risk here (potentially resulting in boredom if it were to fail) but instead played it safe.      Anyway, long story short this film isn't bad. 0671027344|4.0|As I began reading Stephen Chbosky's The Perks of Being a Wallflower I was confused by the format and unsure of the story to follow. I was bothered by the anonymous recipient of Charlie's letter and struggled with the raw and honest voice. But as I continued reading I was quickly absorbed into Charlie's narrative. I became intrigued by his detailed observations of character and honest accounts of the high school experience.    At the start of the novel, Charlie is lonely after the death of his beloved Aunt Helen and the suicide of his closest friend. Through heart-wrenching letters to an unknown classmate, Charlie shares his freshman year. In the first letter Charlie explains, \\"So, this is my life. And I want you to know that I am both happy and sad and I'm still trying to figure out how that could be.\\" When Charlie befriends two seniors, Patrick and Sam, his life becomes more interesting yet more complex. With these newfound friendships, Charlie experiences love, sex, drugs and parties. As a \\"wallflower\\" by nature, Charlie struggles to become involved in the moment while still maintaining his observations.    I became captivated by Charlie's story, I felt exhilarated in his moments of bliss and a part of his pain when he was depressed. Charlie's letters create a story about being alive in the moment and trying to live these moments to their fullest. Charlie's tendencies as a \\"wallflower\\" led him to a life a submission. He is pressured into drugs, drawn into secrets, and thrown into relationships in which he surrenders control. He is easily manipulated by friends and while he enjoys being the loyal yet silent friend, he never shares his own opinions. With the help from his English teacher and mentor, Charlie begins to transform from a \\"wallflower\\" to a person who \\"participates\\" in life. At the end of the novel, Charlie observes, \\"Maybe it's good to put things in perspective. Sometimes, I think that the only perspective is to really be there.\\"    Charlie's realizations about high school and relationships were eye-opening to me. Charlie has the ability to look around the world and at the people who live in our world and accept their strengths and flaws, whatever they might be. We do not know the happiness or pain another individual experiences and therefore we shall not judge them. Chbosky explores this idea through Charlie's prophetic observation of his own high school experience.  While I often pitied Charlie's lack of involvement in high school activities, I found his observations illuminating towards the high school experience.    Although I enjoyed the book, I don't think that The Perks of Being a Wallflower would be universally enjoyed by all. While I enjoyed the novel for description of high school and raw emotions, I do not think this novel would appeal to people over the age of 25. My ability to relate to many of the situations and share similar experiences made the story more realistic and exciting. Although I struggled with the start of the novel, I became engulfed by the text and was moved by the ending of the story. Charlie's freshman year illuminated so many conflicts and dilemmas of the typical high school experience through a series of heart-wrenching letters.

He actually said yes, so I helped him get his undies off and he sat down and, again, chose the Potty book. We didn't even make it through the first page before he peed! I am so glad we got this book because it has helped to positively introduce potty training back into my kiddo's life.<br /><br />The book is very nice because it has simple words. In the books for children that I have read, the vast majority of them are too wordy, and seem as if they are written for much older children (4 yrs). I would assume that the typical potty-training child is around the age of 2-3, and therefore benefit from easy-to-understand, short sentences or phrases, and clear, engaging pictures.
