B000WZB944|5.0|U2 - The Joshua Tree (originally released in 1987)<br /><br />In his liner notes, The Edge wrote that the B-sides, finished a few months after the Joshua Tree was completed, \\"(are) without a doubt the finest U2 work ever not to be included on an album.\\" I was quite gratified to read this as I've felt this way ever since I collected them on vinyl as a teen in the 80s. These tracks alone make the 20th Anniversary JOSHUA TREE album well worth getting. But the whole package, like all of the U2 deluxe editions released so far, is fantastic. It's a wonderful, well-constructed booklet in a sturdy sheath that contains beautiful photographs, excellent liner notes and the lyrics to each song on the original album plus the lyrics to \\"Wave of Sorrow (Birdland).\\"<br /><br />I have to admit that the remaster sounds less than perfect to me - I'm no audiophile but it sounds like it has a bit too much sonic compression - it's very flat sounding. However, The Edge himself was in control of the job. Since he was involved, I trust it came out the way U2 wanted it to. There's something about the sound that doesn't seem quite right to me, but it still sounds acceptable enough and I expect that a good sound system and equalizer could make it sound perfect for the average listener. Still, I am disappointed in the way CDs are remastered these days. I don't see why they can't make a seperate master for downloads and a decent one with plenty of dynamic range for CDs and, of course, vinyl. I guess vinyl is catching on though and CDs are quickly disappearing...<br /><br />I expect that anyone reading this already knows that THE JOSHUA TREE is often considered to be one of the best rock records of all time and a strong candidate for U2's best album ever, so this review will focus on the bonus disk. The first seven tracks were originally released as B-sides in the 80s and the last five tracks are unreleased cuts taken from THE JOSHUA TREE sessions. Coincidentally, this review was posted on the 24th anniversary of the album's original release date...<br /><br />Breakdown:<br /><br />\\"Luminous Times (Hold On To Love)\\" - U2 is known for being an incredibly soulful rock band. Bono strives to \\"reveal rather than conceal\\" as he once put it, and this song ranks among their most heartfelt and emotive. The drums are powerful, lurching, and the keyboards, guitars and vocals evoke fiery passion. *****+<br /><br />\\"Walk To The Water\\" - is one of U2's most unusual recordings and a top-three personal favorite of mine. Its sound is strange - kinda murky, kinda trippy. Adam contributes a meandering bass line while Larry pounds out a quasi-trip-hop beat (before trip-hop even existed!). The guitar parts are clean and meticulously picked, at turns contemplative and soaring. Bono's vocals alternate between melodic spoken words and passionate pleading. *****+<br /><br />\\"Spanish Eyes\\" - a strident rocker, very cool. It's not really one of their best written or most compelling songs, although all the band members turn in solid performances. All the classic U2 elements are in place and Edge's ringing guitar sounds great. Bono's vocals are a little out of control, but he sounds pretty cool regardless. ***3/4<br /><br />\\"Deep In The Heart\\" - This is a mysterious sounding track, similar in mood to \\"Walk To The Water.\\" It's loaded with echo, very spacey and atmospheric. The rhythm is solid, yet it has this sort of open-ended quality. Another personal favorite. *****+<br /><br />\\"Silver And Gold\\" - one of U2's hardest rockin, straight-up rock n' roll tracks ever! It's much better than the original version created for the SUN CITY album (see below). Edge's staggered, heavily reverbed guitars are so cutting. *****+<br /><br />\\"Sweetest Thing\\" - really is a sweet song, a sweet love song. It gently rocks and swings along to a simple repeating keyboard riff. Bono wrote this song for his wife as an apology for having to work in the studio on her birthday. There's a re-recorded version out there, adorned with prettier instrumentaton and background vocals, but this is the original. ****<br /><br />\\"Race Against Time\\" - is a driving, vaguely Middle Eastern-sounding track, way off the beaten path. It reminds me of Pink Floyd's \\"On The Run\\" from THE DARK SIDE OF THE MOON with its scattered feel and runaway train pace, despite the fact that it sounds completely different from that track. Adam Clayton is a good melodic bass player although he's hardly a virtuoso, so I've always suspected his bass part was speeded up on this one. It's mostly an instrumental track but Bono does add some chanting and he sings the words in the title. ****<br /><br />\\"Where The Streets Have No Name (Single Edit)\\" - The opening track on THE JOSHUA TREE, this is without a doubt one of U2's greatest songs - so great in fact that I imagine most people have little use for this truncated version. **** (album version - *****+)<br /><br />\\"Silver And Gold (Sun City)\\" - first appeared on the 1985 SUN CITY album which was created by several artists as a protest against apartheid in South Africa. \\"Silver and Gold\\" was written by Bono during those sessions and features additional guitar by Keith Richards and Ron Wood of The Rolling Stones. This is supposedly Bono's first attempt to write a blues song. It was recorded right after it was written, and to be honest, it shows. Bono hasn't yet found the groove of the song and the Stones' guitars, while cool, just sound kinda tacked on. The U2 rock version is far superior. **3/4<br /><br />\\"Beautiful Ghost/ Introduction To Songs Of Experience\\" - a failed experiment in which the band tries to put some poetry by William Blake (18th century poet and artist) to music. It's a valiant attempt, with subtle and moody atmospherics created with a few elongated Eno-esque tones. Bono picks out a melody for the words that seems fitting, but his vocals sound rather awkward and somehow just don't flow very well. **1/2<br /><br />\\"Wave Of Sorrow (Birdland)\\" - is a compelling song with a classic U2 keyboard sound. It was completed 20 years after the music was first laid down when Bono contributed new vocals and lyrics. ****1/4<br /><br />\\"Desert Of Our Love\\" - a great song with a very cool, kinda funky beat (or U2's approximation of funk at least!) - great drums and piano chords and an acrobatic vocal from Bono. Although it was well recorded, it definitely sounds like a demo - but a very enjoyable one! ****1/2<br /><br />\\"Rise Up\\" - has a jaunty, slightly country feel, very optimistic with touches of banjo here and there. The spirit is willing, but the song itself is less than compelling. ***<br /><br />\\"Drunk Chicken/ America\\" - another strange experiment - this time Bono recites a segment from Allen Ginsberg's beat poem \\"America.\\" The track is only a minute and a half long and has sort of a strange mechanical sound. Larry's drums are arty and very cool sounding. On the first few listens, Bono's vocal sounded really awkward to me, but it sounds kinda cool now that I've gotten used to it. I do find the piece kind of intriguing. It's interesting, but ultimately just a footnote in U2's huge canon of incredible songs. ***1/4s is the original. ****     \\"Race Against Time\\" - is a driving, vaguely Middle Eastern-sounding track, way off the beaten path. It reminds me of Pink Floyd's \\"On The Run\\" from THE DARK SIDE OF THE MOON with its scattered feel and runaway train pace, despite the fact that it sounds completely different from that track. Adam Clayton is a good melodic bass player although he's hardly a virtuoso, so I've always suspected his bass part was speeded up on this one. It's mostly an instrumental track but Bono does add some chanting and he sings the words in the title. ****     \\"Where The Streets Have No Name (Single Edit)\\" - The opening track on THE JOSHUA TREE, this is without a doubt one of U2's greatest songs - so great in fact that I imagine most people have little use for this truncated version. **** (album version - *****+)     \\"Silver And Gold (Sun City)\\" - first appeared on the 1985 SUN CITY album which was created by several artists as a protest against apartheid in South Africa. \\"Silver and Gold\\" was written by Bono during those sessions and features additional guitar by Keith Richards and Ron Wood of The Rolling Stones. This is supposedly Bono's first attempt to write a blues song. It was recorded right after it was written, and to be honest, it shows. Bono hasn't yet found the groove of the song and the Stones' guitars, while cool, just sound kinda tacked on. The U2 rock version is far superior. **3/4     \\"Beautiful Ghost/ Introduction To Songs Of Experience\\" - a failed experiment in which the band tries to put some poetry by William Blake (18th century poet and artist) to music. It's a valiant attempt, with subtle and moody atmospherics created with a few elongated Eno-esque tones. Bono picks out a melody for the words that seems fitting, but his vocals sound rather awkward and somehow just don't flow very well. **1/2     \\"Wave Of Sorrow (Birdland)\\" - is a compelling song with a classic U2 keyboard sound. It was completed 20 years after the music was first laiddown when Bono contributed new vocals and lyrics. ****1/4     \\"Desert Of Our Love\\" - a great song with a very cool, kinda funky beat (or U2's approximation of funk at least!) - great drums and piano chords and an acrobatic vocal from Bono. Although it was well recorded, it definitely sounds like a demo - but a very enjoyable one! ****1/2     \\"Rise Up\\" - has a jaunty, slightly country feel, very optimistic with touches of banjo here and there. The spirit is willing, but the song itself is less than compelling. ***     \\"Drunk Chicken/ America\\" - another strange experiment - this time Bono recites a segment from Allen Ginsberg's beat poem \\"America.\\" The track is only a minute and a half long and has sort of a strange mechanical sound. Larry's drums are arty and very cool sounding. On the first few listens, Bono's vocal sounded really awkward to me, but it sounds kinda cool now that I've gotten used to it. I do find the piece kind of intriguing. It's interesting, but ultimately just a footnote in U2's huge canon of incredible songs. ***1/4

0812973992|4.0|Let the Great World Spin, by Colum McCann, was one of the most enjoyable books that I have read in recent memory.  This quick-paced book, that chronicles the lives of twelve distinct and unique characters, is perfect for all ages and for people from all walks of life, because the author explores extremely different types of people and their distinct relationships with 1970's New York.   Stylistically, McCann utilizes a different narrator for each chapter.  At first, I found this to be confusing and altogether unpleasant, but as the book progressed I found that it complemented and added to the themes of the story.  Irish immigrants, New York City hookers, mourning upper-class mothers, judges and hackers seem to have nothing in common, yet McCann has the ability to link them together, create similarities and provide opportunities to understand the nuances of life in NYC.  We understand how each individual and each class come together to contribute to society.  The link among all people in the story is Philippe Petit's 1974 tight rope walk across the twin towers.  McCann proves that seemingly polar and opposite people have similarities.  Shared experiences help bind people and bring them together.  It was extremely interesting to see how this one event could be witnessed and experienced by such a unique group of people and from such varying perspectives.  Petit's tremendous feat, walking from one twin tower to the other on a wire provides an opportunity for the characters to learn and reflect on themselves.  Additionally, it provides hope and a feeling that anything can be accomplished, even in the bleak and seemingly hopeless lives of our protagonists.   I also really enjoyed McCann's ability to develop setting and introduce characters.  No matter the type of place or the traits of a character, McCann vividly and aptly depicts the scene.  Most notably, at least for me, is his introduction of the lowly tenement district of New York.  For the characters that live in the projects, nothing is easy.  McCann's depiction of the setting truly sets us up for the feeling of hopelessness and despair of the projects, \\"On one side was a row of high-rise tenements behind a chain-link fence.  Parts of the fence were topped with razor wire.  On the other, the expressway: the light-streak of cars zipping above.  Below, by the underpass, a long line of women.  Cars and trucks were pulling into the shadows.  The women struck poses.\\" (24)  McCann's description is clear, concise, and easily understood.  Even for someone who has never visited NYC, the scene can easily be visualized and understood.  His juxtaposition of what is seen  (the highway) and what is hidden (the prostitutes) is interesting and well-thought out.   A final trait of McCann's writing that stood out to me was his ability to play with and take on any voice necessary.  The narrative voice could be an Irish `monk', a hooker or an ordinary woman, \\"The days I recall finest were about as ordinary as they come--playing hopscotch on the slab of broken concrete, following my brothers through the cornfields, trailing my schoolbag through the dust.  My older brothers and I read a lot of books back then--a bookmobile came around our street once every few months, staying fifteen minutes.\\" (285)  This writing is just so beautiful--simple, yet descriptive.  Voice is the device that McCann explores most frequently.  He expertly changes his voice and tone as he changes character.   All in all, I give this book a resounding A+.  Everything about the writing, plot and style made me fall in love with the story and its characters.  I couldn't put it down.
B002KYHZLQ|2.0|Maybe it got better after the first third of the book. I'll never know. 0061726826|3.0|(I'm reviewing the ARC of this book).    Delirium is the sophomore effort by Lauren Oliver who shot to recognition with Before I Fall. It is set in a dystopian America after the \\"disease\\" of love (or any passionate emotion) has been largely eradicated by brainwashing, social control, medication, and surgery in order to maintain a calm, ordered society. Youngsters look forward to their 18th birthday when they can undergo the \\"cure\\" so they'll never be afflicted by unruly passions. Government patrols and cultural values do a good job of keeping them \\"safe\\" until they can have their blessed lobotomies, and any \\"infected\\" are soon dealt with, but our main character, Lena, is not the typical girl of her time.     Lena is an orphan whose mother was incurable and became infected; Lena has been raised with that stigma by her aunt and uncle and longingly awaits her cure. However, a series of events begins to alert her that all is not right and people are not well under this system. Lena meets a mysterious young man, Alex, who inspires her to think for herself and act in unprogrammed ways. He also convinces her to search out the truth concerning her mother.     The book's premise is compelling and the main characters are quite sympathetic, particularly Alex. There aren't any twists I didn't see coming but there is action, intrigue and plenty of turmoil. I enjoyed the story and was touched by the ending even if it didn't surprise me. I did feel the writing tended to bog down in description that interrupted the action, at times clumsily, but it was still a page-turner. I definitely plan to read the next book in the series.

B0034G4OVS|1.0|Too bad it was marketed as a \\"HORROR\\" film.  That is my first problem with this movie.  At no time is it even close to being scary or horrific in any way.<br /><br />***SPOLIER ALERT***<br /><br />Let me start by saying that this is by far one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time.  If you like movies about unlikable characters making ridiculous and improbable choices, with a few scenes of forced frights, poor effects, and cheap gore, then this is the movie for you!<br /><br />First off, we meet our 3 main characters.  There are 2 douchebag guys and one idiot blonde girl who at no time reveal any redeeming qualities whatsoever.  Believe me, by the end of this movie you will be screaming at your tv \\"Oh for crying out loud!  Die already!\\"  There are several \\"talky\\" scenes thrown in as attempts to get the audience to relate to the characters, but to no avail.<br /><br />Secondly, I honestly can't remember the last time I laughed at a movie that wasn't supposed to be funny but was so bad I couldn't help myself.  Case in point, there is a scene where, after being stranded on the chair lift for several hours, the best idea these yahoos can come up with is for one of them to jump to the ground, and this is AFTER the guy in the snowplow has already come and gone.  At least if he would've jumped when the snowplow was there they would have been saved.  Sure he might've suffered the same broken legs, but at least after being treated at the ER he could've joined his friends for a drink by the fire!  Anyway, I digress...so the guy is lying on the ground, legs all busted up, and yet I found myself laughing out loud at how ridiculous it looked, not to mention how unrealistic it was.  Shouldn't have shock set in at some point??  And as if that wasn't bad enough, WOLVES show up!  And not just any wolves, but HUNGRY wolves...wolves who feed on human flesh!  Perhaps if there was one or two skinny, malnourished wolves who were obviously starving to death, this idea might have been easier to swallow.  But such is not the case...these are an entire pack of what appear to be perfectly healthy wolves.  At this point, I slapped my forehead.  Really?  When I find myself and those around me are laughing at a guy getting eaten by wolves, I know there is something really wrong with the movie.<br /><br />Third, and I'll make this my last, I promise...these people are stranded on a ski lift for days, and we are to believe that they are in some sort of sub-freezing temps??  Maybe it's because I grew up in the upper Midwestern US, and have experienced real cold, but I found it very hard to believe because, even though they kept pointing out that they both indeed had frostbite on their faces, how did these people not think that maybe zipping up their coats completely and wearing their hoods might help them keep warm?  How about curling up with your legs closer to your body?  Or snuggling together for the body heat??  Not once did I ever feel like these people were cold, let alone freezing!  And it isn't that they chose not to do what they could to stay warm but that their survival instincts never kicked in to try and keep them from freezing to death??  And the part with the girl's hand freezing to the metal bar? Are you serious?!  Her hand is exposed to the cold all night and the only injury she sustains is her hand sticking to the metal a la the kid's tongue in A Christmas Story?!  C'mon!  These people never even shiver!<br /><br />I agree that the acting was sub-par, but I often feel if the story is well-written, poor acting can sometimes be forgiven, especially in a \\"Horror\\" film.  But this was just a terribly written script.  I felt that my intelligence was completely insulted after sitting through the entirety of this movie.  Am I really supposed to feel for these people or believe any of what I am seeing?!  I literally came up with at least 5 simple solutions to their predicament in the first 5 minutes of them being \\"stuck\\"!  I could even forgive the unlikely scenario that they are stranded without a cell phone in this day and age, but the numerous other plot holes were so gaping it was frustrating to watch.  I was exhausted by how angry I got by the end of this.  All the laughing certainly wore me out also.<br /><br />This is worse than B movie stuff because it tries to be smart and stylish and it is really just one big joke from start to finish.  So watch if you must, but don't pay too much...luckily for me I watched it after a friend rented it, so all I really lost was an hour and a half of my life that I will never get back...without a cell phone in this day and age, but the numerous other plot holes were so gaping it was frustrating to watch.  I was exhausted by how angry I got by the end of this.  All the laughing certainly wore me out also.    This is worse than B movie stuff because it tries to be smart and stylish and it is really just one big joke from start to finish.  So watch if you must, but don't pay too much...luckily for me I watched it after a friend rented it, so all I really lost was an hour and a half of my life that I will never get back...

B0001RVTXO|3.0|I hate to be that guy who reviews a greatest hits album by his favorite band and puts it down for being an incomplete waste, but since no one else seemed to want to do it, I suppose the task was left on me. I know you've probably heard this a thousand times but, with a few exceptions, greatest hits albums are a poor choice for an introduction to a band, especially a great band like the Pixies. The reason I say this is simple - this band is so good you'll almost certainly want to buy all of their albums eventually anyway. (They only have four, not counting \\"Come On Pilgrim.\\") For just as cheap, you could get their greatest, most accessible album, \\"Doolittle.\\" If you don't like that album, you don't like the Pixies. It's as simple as that. From there, you could easily just go ahead and buy \\"Surfer Rosa,\\" \\"Bossanova,\\" and \\"Trompe le Monde\\" and pretty quickly have all the Pixies' albums. All of them are absolutely essential and include several tracks not present here that are as good or better than the tracks that are included on this compilation album. I'm just trying to save you a few bucks, as it's inexcusable to have just a greatest hits album for this band anyway, and for not much more money you could get the complete discography. The one and only reason this collection was released was for the record company to capitalize on the Pixies' 2004 reunion tour. At least \\"Death to the Pixies\\" had the bonus live disc. There's no new or unreleased material on this thing at all, rendering this collection completely pointless for both hardcore fans and newcomers.    Proper albums the tracks included on this compilation can be found on:  \\"Come On Pilgrim (EP)\\" (1987) - \\"Nimrod's Son,\\" \\"The Holiday Song,\\" \\"Caribou\\"  \\"Surfer Rosa\\" (1988) - \\"Bone Machine,\\" \\"Broken Face,\\" \\"Gigantic (album version),\\" \\"Vamos,\\" \\"Where Is My Mind?\\"  \\"Doolittle\\" (1989) - \\"Hey,\\" \\"Monkey Gone to Heaven,\\" \\"Debaser,\\" \\"Gouge Away,\\" \\"Wave of Mutilation,\\" \\"Here Comes Your Man\\"  \\"Bossanova\\" (1990) - \\"Velouria,\\" \\"Allison,\\" \\"Dig for Fire\\"  \\"Trompe le Monde\\" (1991) - \\"U-Mass,\\" \\"Alec Eiffel,\\" \\"Planet of Sound\\"  \\"Death to the Pixies (Compilation/Live Album)\\" (1997) - \\"Gigantic (single version)\\"  \\"Complete B-Sides (Compilation)\\" (2001) - \\"Into the White,\\" \\"Winterlong\\"    If you have all of the albums listed above, as well as \\"Pixies at the BBC\\" and the 2002 self-titled EP simply called \\"Pixies\\" that collected the other nine songs from the \\"Come On Pilgrim\\" sessions that were originally recorded for, along with the \\"Pilgrim\\" tracks, a demo called \\"The Purple Tape,\\" then you will have a more or less complete Pixies collection. This so-called \\"best of\\" album is completely inessential. Skip over this one, no matter your level of fanaticism.

0812973992|4.0|This novel by Colum McCann exemplifies the true spirit of New York City. It is a well-written and brilliant portrait of New York. As McCann travels through various personalities, he manages to tie them together by seemingly mundane actions. The raw emotions of New Yorkers, from a Park Avenue judge to prostitutes in the Bronx, capture the true chaotic essence of the city. Through his use of multiple characters, settings, and narration styles, McCann unveils different aspects of New York in every chapter. Each story and perspective happens in what feels like an eerie parallel universe with intertwining events which hold the stories together at the edges. \\"It had never occurred to me before but everything in New York is built upon another thing, nothing is entirely by itself, each thing is as strange as the last, and connected\\" (pg. 306). McCann successfully shows me a complex and intimately connected New York City landscape.  I appreciate McCann's efforts to apply a \\"six degrees of separation\\" aspect to his novel, yet it is occasionally overbearing. At the core of the novel, a tightrope walker walks between the World Trade Center towers and he inevitably affects each person in the world below him. Judge Soloman, who tries the walker in court, doesn't think about the act in the same manner as his wife Claire, or as the walker himself does. To Soloman, the verdict regarding the tightrope walker is a huge deal. His appreciation for the walker doesn't end at the successful court day it handed to him; he also acknowledges the art that the tightrope walker managed to present. \\"He had made himself into a statue, but a perfect New York one, a temporary one, up in the air, high above the city. A statue that had no regard for the past.... So brash. So glassy. So forward-looking\\" (pg. 248). However, to an isolated couple who live in a cabin, a fleeting newspaper article is the most they see of the act.  Although the various perspectives make the novel stronger, some snippets ofseemingly meaningless stories are included as well. Hackers from California, who \\"view\\" the tightrope walker through calls to pay phones in New York, merely shows the chaos of the city without their actually being there. I didn't fully grasp why that story is strewn into the mix, and it took a little while to fully recognize the voice of that particular chapter. Occasionally, it took a few pages of each new chapter to identify the narrator and the storyline behind voice, which in turn led to me missing some of the key thoughts--I ended up skimming certain details which I didn't know were crucial until I uncovered this voice of the chapter. This, however, also made me reread parts of chapters, which aided my overall comprehension and appreciation of the novel.   Another aspect of this novel that I didn't like included the fact that I resonated with some of the storylines more than others. The novel discusses two brothers' childhoods in Ireland, a monk Corrigan and his more sensible brother Ciaran, and McCann practically \\"raises\\" them throughout the beginning of the novel. The brothers end up in the Bronx and we travel through their lives alongside them. I felt as I had more desire to read and understand Corrigan and Ciaran than other characters because McCann discusses both their childhood and adulthood, and also because Ciaran contributes to a significant amount of narration--something that the other characters are missing. However, this storyline fades as the novel continues, which I disliked.   This novel's depth is truly outstanding. It incorporates a multitude of views on New York, from the Twins Towers representing \\"...the sky, the night, the colors: progress, beauty, capitalism\\" (pg. 248) to the evils of the city, where \\"Hooking was born in [Tillie]. That's no exaggeration\\" (pg. 199). Although the connections among portraits are sometimes obscure and only apparent to the reader, I believe that McCann successfully reveals demographic diversity at its best, andat its worst.

1563899426|5.0|This is my first entry into the comic book/graphic novel world. I wanted something that wasn't too \\"dark\\". This book clearly serves that purpose. I really enjoyed, often laughing, reading this first in the series of graphic novels. The connection to memories from my past coupled with modern day language and situations made this an easy read. I can't get enough of the series.

B003VR5PPY|5.0|You would think you would eventually get bored working through the various parts of the story for each of the 6 endings, but it's addicting until the end...when you're wishing it weren't over.  Make sure to take notes as you go on everything, espcially on the door combinations, because the various endings are unlocked by trying different door combinations.<br /><br />Tip: the game will tell you, once you finish one ending, that you can click hold the left direction key to skip faster during all the text/talking.  I found that if you HOLD BOTH left buttons it fastforwards smoothly and much faster...you won't have to keep clicking to progress the text.

B00005K3OT|2.0|Don't get me wrong, this movie is inspirational, uplifting, visually enticing, and utterly appropriate for a feel good movie. It is also simplistic, predictable, stereotyping, and contains one dimensional characters.<br /><br />First of all, the main character Vianne, is totally unrealistic. She travels from village to village and sets up a chocolate shop each time. How and where does she get the ingredients, not to mention, the ability to lug all her equipment is not explained. Throughout the movie, she constantly gives truffles and hot chocolates to the villagers in order to win their favor. Of course people want to be your friend if you give them free chocolate, but that is not a very sustainable way of running a business. And in a town where people have a moral bias against eating chocolate, it seems like you wouldn't have that much wiggle room to be buying pearl necklaces from gypsies, wearing nice clothes all the time, and serving four course meals to half the village for a friend's birthday. Realistically her part could only have been fulfilled by a rich woman selling chocolates as a hobby instead of an independent entrepreneur.<br /><br />I was also disturbed by the essentialization of Mayan culture in the movie. The story of the movie is that of injecting primitive, passionate, spicy, sexual, natural pre-Columbian culture (by way of chocolate) into sensually deprived Christian European culture. This is hardly the truth about either culture and in a movie about tolerance and overcoming stereotypes, the movie's portrayal of these cultures reinforces conventional stereotypes. Even in the most conservative christian societies, countercultures of promiscuity, drunkenness, revelry, and alternative spirituality flourished and were often an accepted part of daily life. Western cultures for centuries have exoticized Asian, African, native American and pre-columbian peoples as noble savages that live in an Edenic state. The movie merely reinforces these traditional stereotypes.<br /><br />My  third criticism of this movie is its simplistic message that indulging the senses solves Christian society's ills. If only people ate more chocolate then they would all be friends, have great sex, and become tolerant of outsiders. Especially in an age of rampant materialism and over stimulation of the senses, this is too simple a message for our times. Today, sugar is easy to come by. Over consumption of rich foods have led to obesity, short attention spans, and every kind of health problem out there. Young people  especially are motivated by sex, instant gratification, and stimulation of the senses as a way of filling the vacuum left by the absence of religion or spiritual meaning in their lives. A century ago, a dose of sensual gratification may have been remedy for our uptight grandparents, but today we see what a lives devoted to the fulfillment of instant sensual indulgence does for individual health, societies and the environment. At least an acknowledgment of this dichotomy would have made this film more than what it is, a simplistic, corn syrupy feel good movie that reinforces our preconceptions.My  third criticism of this movie is its simplistic message that indulging the senses solves Christian society's ills. If only people ate more chocolate then they would all be friends, have great sex, and become tolerant of outsiders. Especially in an age of rampant materialism and over stimulation of the senses, this is too simple a message for our times. Today, sugar is easy to come by. Over consumption of rich foods have led to obesity, short attention spans, and every kind of health problem out there. Young people  especially are motivated by sex, instant gratification, and stimulation of the senses as a way of filling the vacuum left by the absence of religion or spiritual meaning in their lives. A century ago, a dose of sensual gratification may have been remedy for our uptight grandparents, but today we see what a lives devoted to the fulfillment of instant sensual indulgence does for individual health, societies and the environment. At least an acknowledgment of this dichotomy would have made this film more than what it is, a simplistic, corn syrupy feel good movie that reinforces our preconceptions.
159420229X|5.0|The brain makes up just 2% of a human's mass, yet consumes 20% of the oxygen and 25% of the glucose we use. Unfortunately, researchers at UCLA have concluded that we use only 20% of its memory capability (Scientific American, 4/19/2007). On average, people reportedly waste 40 days/year compensating for things they've forgotten. In \\"Moonwalking with Einstein\\" author Joshua Foer went from being one of those forgetful folks to champion at the U.S. Memory Championship after a year of memory training. His book summarizes the latest research, as well as several ancient techniques (eg. 'the method of loci' - aka 'memory palace,' dating back to 477 B.C.) to memorize speeches and even entire books. Much of the book is taken up with Foer's training.<br /><br />Foer begins telling readers that when Gutenberg turned books into mass-produced commodities, it became less important to remember what the printed page could. (Book indexes further reduced the need for memory.) Memory training until then was considered a centerpiece of classical education, along with grammar, logic, and rhetoric. Fortunately, during the last decades of the 20th century, these techniques have been resurrected, mainly by memory contest competitors (introduced to the U.S. in 1997) and those hoping to make money training others. The 'good news' is that becoming a memory master is not a matter of inheriting superior genes - per Foer, there is only one case described of 'photographic memory' described in the scientific literature. (\\"Rain Man\\" Kim Peek, the savant who could recite all of Shakespeare's works, etc., had an IQ of only 87.) The 'bad news' is that it takes hard work and creativity.<br /><br />Research in the mid-50s established that most can only think about roughly seven items (plus/minus two) at a time. Fortunately, 'chunking' is a way to decrease the number of items to remember by increasing their size, and provides the logic behind phone, credit-card, and Social Security number structures.<br /><br />A second useful research hint comes from examples of those with naturally superior memories. They're likely to have 'synesthesia' - sounds (including word pronunciation) to them are accompanied by color, texture, even taste. Thus, every word conjures up an image. Numbers may have their own personalities - '1' = a strong man, '2' = a slim woman, '8' = a very stout woman, etc. For synesthiacs, simple stories may become impossible to understand because the image-making bogs down their minds. Regardless, for them learning facts, etc. in sequence involves eg. imagining a walk down a known street while associating activities, etc. with various locations en route. Alternatively, a mental walk through familiar buildings, or train-ride station stops can be used - as long as there's some semblance of order linking one locus to the next.<br /><br />Researchers have also found that our brains remember visual imagery much better than other forms. Thus, it easier for us to remember 'baker' (occupation) than 'Baker' (name) because the occupation brings up images of what a baker does and looks like. Thus, the secret to remembering names, for example, is to turn Bakers into bakers, Foers into fours, Reagans into ray guns, etc. Generalizing this approach is key to strengthening memory, part of the method Cicero is said to have used, was independently developed by Australian aborigines and Southwest Indian Apaches, and is used by all top memorizers today to one degree or another.<br /><br />Continuing, Foer points out that the more associative hooks a new piece of information has (eg. smell, taste), the more securely it gets embedded into one's long-term memory - especially if one \\"revisits the memory palace later in the day, again the next, and the following week.\\" (Example: Imagine the first item on a grocery list one wants to memorize is bread, then eggs. In your mental walk from your bedroom to your kitchen mentally place a loaf of bread on your bed, eggs on your dresser, etc.) Also, the funnier, lewder, and more bizarre the hooks used, the better - eg. an image of Claudia Schiffer swimming nude in a tub of cottage cheese at one's front door. Expertise in the subject being learned/memorized also helps.<br /><br />Few, if any, use the memory palace approach to memorizing speeches and poems. Poets like Homer relied on repetition and rhythms to recite their work from memory (New York Times, 3/08/11).  Foer also reports that alliteration, dynamic images, songs, cliches, words that rhyme are more easily memorized. Turns out that those memorizing long poems and books don't do it totally verbatim.<br /><br />Those developing their memory quickly hit a performance plateau - Foer reports that setting higher goals and analyzing one's performance problems are essential to further progress. Foer contends that these barriers are more psychological than physical - thus, the sudden flood of milers beating the 4-minute mile barrier after Roger Bannister first did. Improvement requires feedback, and with that feedback eg. surgeons get better over time; interestingly, mammograph readers get much less less, if any, feedback, and their performance may deteriorate over time. To prevent this, memory experts suggest they practice on old cases where the outcome is already known.<br /><br />There are five events in the U.S. Memory Championships that Foer won. One is memorizing 99 names and faces within 15 minutes and recalling them in another 20. Another is memorizing an unpublished 50-line poem in 15 minutes; contestants must also memorize a list of random numbers, random words, and a shuffled deck of cards. The best associate every group of three cards into a sentence - the first card is a person, the second a verb, and the third an object. Similarly, they may remember every six digits as a sentence.<br /><br />Turns out that most memorizers have weaknesses - those good a remembering digits are often bad at names and faces. Poetry memorizers are often bad at cards.<br /><br />Finally, near the end of \\"Moonwalking with Einstein,\\" Foer raises the question \\" Why work to improve memory?\\" The answer - \\"How we perceive the world and act in it are products of what we remember.\\" Foer uses his trip to China as an example - while enjoyable, it would have been much more meaningful if he knew Chinese history.<br /><br />Bottom-Line: \\"Moonwalking with Einstein\\" is an interesting and useful read. Unfortunately, written material, lists, cellphone contact lists, computerized reminder systems, and Google are too easy to use as alternatives. Now I need something that motivates me to use Foer's material - perhaps explaining card-counting strategies. Foer says the best can memorize the sequence of a deck of cards within 21 seconds.d more bizarre the hooks used, the better - eg. an image of Claudia Schiffer swimming nude in a tub of cottage cheese at one's front door. Expertise in the subject being learned/memorized also helps.     Few, if any, use the memory palace approach to memorizing speeches and poems. Poets like Homer relied on repetition and rhythms to recite their work from memory (New York Times, 3/08/11).  Foer also reports that alliteration, dynamic images, songs, cliches, words that rhyme are more easily memorized. Turns out that those memorizing long poems and books don't do it totally verbatim.     Those developing their memory quickly hit a performance plateau - Foer reports that setting higher goals and analyzing one's performance problems are essential to further progress. Foer contends that these barriers are more psychological than physical - thus, the sudden flood of milers beating the 4-minute mile barrier after Roger Bannister first did. Improvement requires feedback, and with that feedback eg. surgeons get better over time; interestingly, mammograph readers get much less less, if any, feedback, and their performance may deteriorate over time. To prevent this, memory experts suggest they practice on old cases where the outcome is already known.     There are five events in the U.S. Memory Championships that Foer won. One is memorizing 99 names and faces within 15 minutes and recalling them in another 20. Another is memorizing an unpublished 50-line poem in 15 minutes; contestants must also memorize a list of random numbers, random words, and a shuffled deck of cards. The best associate every group of three cards into a sentence - the first card is a person, the second a verb, and the third an object. Similarly, they may remember every six digits as a sentence.     Turns out that most memorizers have weaknesses - those good a remembering digits are often bad at names and faces. Poetry memorizers are often bad at cards.     Finally, near the end of \\"Moonwalking with Einstein,\\" Foer raises the question \\" Why work to improve memory?\\" The answer - \\"How we perceive the world and act in it are products of what we remember.\\" Foer uses his trip to China as an example - while enjoyable, it would have been much more meaningful if he knew Chinese history.     Bottom-Line: \\"Moonwalking with Einstein\\" is an interesting and useful read. Unfortunately, written material, lists, cellphone contact lists, computerized reminder systems, and Google are too easy to use as alternatives. Now I need something that motivates me to use Foer's material - perhaps explaining card-counting strategies. Foer says the best can memorize the sequence of a deck of cards within 21 seconds.
B000002OOY|3.0|Dont know if it was bad luck or I got bamboozled but I never received the CD.  jachujanan has good ratings so Im going to use the benefit of the doubt and say that something bad happened.  Nonetheless, Im saddened.
B002ZG98FU|3.0|\\"Morning Glory\\" is predictable but watchable.  The story is about a young female TV producer, Becky Fuller, (Rachel Adams), who loses her job.  She moves in with her parents and frantically searches for another job to get out of a \\"told you so\\" situation.  She finally lands a Morning Show job as Executive Producer, but the show's ratings are in the dumps.  Working with feuding co-hosts (Harrison Ford and Diane Keaton) keeps her hopping and hoping that something will \\"click.\\"  Nothing seems to be working, and the show seems dull and lifeless.  Soon her boss (played by Jeff Goldblum) calls her in to say the show is cancelled.  Becky begs for one more chance... and the rest is history.<br /><br />Overall the movie is entertaining, and you hope Becky, the young TV producer, will succeed.  She has many obstructions to overcome, but, like the Ever Ready Bunny, she keeps trying and trying.  The movie gets funny toward the end and, of course, Becky saves the day.
B000R9EG3Q|1.0|I read this book hoping to gain some perspective on how President Obama came to his ideas about our country, none of which I agree on.    What I found was a constant bashing from the black man on the white man. His mother, a white woman, raised him as best she could and shielded him so well from racism that he did not even know it existed until he had his first black friend in high school--a friend who poisoned his mind with pure hate for white people. Then, as if Obama was mad at his mother for not doing the same, he deserted her after high school and became more associated with more radical, white-person-hate-filled blacks. I don't understand how his mom concludes Barack gets his \\"honesty and good character\\" from his father, who deserted him as a toddler and eventually became a bitter drunk.     I think it is not coincidental that Obama holds such negative beliefs about white people, yet never experienced racism himself and is the President of the United States. If this doesn't prove that black people are offered as much opportunity as whites, I do not know what does.    Anyone who walks away from this book \\"inspired\\" I would quickly have to ask why/how. It is scary to think this kind of talk proliferates in the black community. Black men tearing each other down and constantly blaming their failures on the \\"white man\\" will not progress black men any further. Black men deserting the mothers of their children and not raising their children, in particular their boys, will do nothing to raise that particular segment of the community along. I know plenty of successful black people, and I can rest assured they do not look for racism in the faces of every white person they see, nor blame their problems on the \\"white man.\\"     White people have struggles too--I struggled my whole life and was told many times I would fail, yet I am here and have managed to accomplish most of what I set out to do. I have also experienced racism from blacks yet do not hold it against them. Racism exists within every community and every race. Yet I would have to argue that where I see most racism playing out today is actually within the black community. If \\"certain\\" oppressed black people want to move up in the world, then they should (1) commit and stay with the mother of your child/children and (2) stop blaming others for your mistakes and ignore what you may think to be racism. Constantly tearing each others dreams down and calling each other the \\"n\\" word, while saying the white man will never let you get anywhere does NOTHING for progress.    I opened this book hoping for a deeper understanding of a man I did not understand. I walked away with it more disgusted with racism and perpetual hate within the black community.

Unfortunately, researchers at UCLA have concluded that we use only 20% of its memory capability (Scientific American, 4/19/2007). Foer contends that these barriers are more psychological than physical - thus, the sudden flood of milers beating the 4-minute mile barrier after Roger Bannister first did. To prevent this, memory experts suggest they practice on old cases where the outcome is already known.     There are five events in the U.S. Memory Championships. One is memorizing 99 names and faces within 15 minutes and recalling them in another 20. Another is memorizing an unpublished 50-line poem in 15 minutes; contestants must also memorize a list of random numbers, random words, and a shuffled deck of cards. The best associate every group of three cards into a sentence - the first card is a person, the second a verb, and the third an object. Similarly, they may remember every six digits as a sentence.     Turns out that most memorizers have weaknesses - those good a remembering digits are often bad at names and faces. Poetry memorizers are often bad at cards.     Finally, near the end of \\"Moonwalking with Einstein,\\" Foer raises the question \\" Why work to improve memory?\\" The answer - \\"How we perceive the world and act in it are products of what we remember.\\" Foer uses his trip to China as an example - while enjoyable, it would have been much more meaningful if he knew Chinese history.     Bottom-Line: \\"Moonwalking with Einstein\\" is an interesting and useful read. Unfortunately, written material, lists, cellphone contact lists, computerized reminder systems, and Google are too easy to use as alternatives. Now I need something that motivates me to use Foer's material - perhaps explaining card-counting strategies. Foer says the best can memorize the sequence of a deck of cards within 21 seconds.
031603438X|5.0|I thought this was a great book (I have the audio version) - reading some of the reviews, it appears people don't really have a clue about what or who they are listening to at any given time. : ) When I first got it, I thought, \\"Geez - 8 million discs; this will be unbelievably tedious!\\" I have discovered, it's not at all. Richards does a bang-up job of remembering so much detail - heck, I can't even remember where I park my car when I go shopping. That's why it's so long - he has incredible recall. And, previously unbeknownst to me, he is interesting, intelligent, and has a great sense of humor about himself and his persona. I am mostly impressed at his own quest for knowledge and how he is really just a guy. Just a guy who loves music and learning about who he is and the world around him. He makes no bones about or excuses for some of the looney things he's done, and he pulls no punches and tells it like it is and matter-of-factly, in regard to himself and others.     I wish more people were as straight up as this guy is, and he realizes that, at the end of the day, we aren't really all that different - it's just some of us get seen much more when we do our jobs.     Admittedly, I was a bit unimpressed when Joe Hurley started narrating - as I'm quite the Johnny Depp fan, and I honestly thought Hurley was faking his British accent some - however, I've since learned that he is, indeed, a Londoner himself, and instead of going out of his way to possibly imitate Richards, he instead gives his recitation a good taste of Richard's developing 60's and 70's persona.     I'm only about halfway through the audiobook yet, and though I kinda sorta liked Keith Richards well enough over the years, and always thought him oddly interesting, not being a huge Stones fan, I didn't think about them too much. However, after listening to this book and understanding more about the guy, I have to say, I very much look forward to hearing the rest of it, and the book's turned me into a true Keith Richards fan. I give him credit for being just who he is, for better or worse, and there, in my opinion, can't be too much wrong with people who are as upfront as he is.

B002ZG9774|2.0|It used to be an unwritten \\"standard\\" that DVDs would allow you to press the \\"menu\\" button to skip all the ads and previews and go directly to the movie's menu.  Not here.  The greedy suits at Sony have front-loaded this disk with two mandatory ads for Sony hardware, followed by four previews for other movies.  These are programmed so the Menu and Search keys are locked out.  And when you fast-forward, they have included a code to cancel the FF as soon as the next ad or preview starts.  Two years from now if I want to enjoy this movie again I will still have to plough through six ads for hardware that is no longer made and movies that have been long forgotten.    Oh, and if your Blu-ray player is internet-connected, there is yet another ad embedded in the main menu, hawking various internet streaming services.  C'mon Sony, enough is enough!    I wanted to give this one star, but the movie is too good for that.  Had the disk not been encumbered by such in-your-face advertising I would have given it five stars.  So I'm knocking off three stars for greed.    Oh, and, BTW, the movie was great.

0887306667|3.0|This is an outstanding book.  It's a quick read, captivating, and compelling.  The advice it offers is mostly sound and, to some degree, has what appears to be a timeless element to it.  However, the claim to &#34;immutability&#34; of the laws is a bit overstated, and I think at times the authors are guilty of faulty reasoning.  The authors weave a convincing narrative, but when the chips are down, they still are picking and choosing facts to support their arguments, based on hindsights.  This book has aged somewhat, allowing the predictions to be tested.  Some of them hold, others do not.  The most glaringly false predictions lie in the realm of computers and software.  The authors predict that competitors to Microsoft will succeed in certain markets, such as word processing software, or Lotus in the spreadsheet market (or groupware market).  In reality, Microsoft crushed Lotus and Wordperfect, and it did so not by utilizing any of the marketing laws, but by exerting its monopoly power, leveraging its dominance in the operating system market.  And in perhaps an even worse prediction, the authors claimed that Lotus &#34;owned&#34; the word groupware, according to the laws of the book--and yet now Lotus doesn't even appear once in the first TWENTY pages of google search results on &#34;groupware&#34;.  But it's impossible to predict the future perfectly, and many of the other predictions in this book have come true over time.  Where does this book go wrong?  It is limited in its scope.  Note that the examples of failed predictions all come from the realm of information technology.  This book is limited in scope because of the cultural and societal changes being brought about by the information age.  The laws work well in mainstream consumerist society, dominated by television and a uniform suburban culture with big, corporate chain stores, television, and uniform suburban subdivisions.  This is the America of the 50's.  But this society is breaking down, declining.It's being replaced with alternatives coming from many different angles: the information age has created wonders such as social media and the blogosphere, which are giving rise to a more decentralized distribution of information.  On a grass-roots level, small towns and new urbanism, allied to leaders in small business, are changing the structure of communities, also moving away from corporate consumerism.  The laws described in this book are not immutable laws nor are they an inevitable result of the free market -- they're an inevitable result of a large, centralized society run by a small number of big corporations, and with a centralized media that is largely centered around television.  Many markets in today's world already behave very differently.  In the community of businesses with a local scope, often the most important thing for a brand to do is to simply persist beyond the first two years.  The laws of this book only really work for national, global, or large regional brands.  Another example of where these laws break down is ecommerce.  Sites like eBay, Half.com, and Etsy, which are major brands that seem to follow the laws of the book, have ironically created a different atmosphere where these laws don't apply--the thousands of &#34;power sellers&#34; on eBay compete on roughly equal footing with newer, smaller users.  Price and reputation drive decisions, not seller identity.  Another example which is an area I work in directly, as I run RateTea, is the online tea retailer market.  The largest player, Adagio teas, doesn't have a huge chunk of the market, and there are literally hundreds of successful, profitable online tea retailers.  This diversity is fueled by bloggers and a sea of individual users on social networking sites, which do the marketing for these companies, in a patchwork, decentralized fashion.  This atmosphere creates diversity of opinion and doesn't allow the sort of consolidation of brand power and brand loyalty that you see in the sort of system of TV + Chain Store + Products from Large Corporations.  Criticisms aside?  Still a great book.  Consumerism may be on the decline but we're stuck with it for a few more generations and if you're in business, you still want to know how to navigate it.  And this book is one of the quickest ways to empower yourself to succeed as a marketer in mainstream consumerist society.

193413712X|2.0|I picked up this book at the airport in Toronto only because I heard it won a Pulitzer prize and because I needed something to read on the flight to Fort McMurry. A 200 page novel, that has won an important prize should definitely keep me interested for the close to four hours flight. So I was excited. I expected to finish the book in one go. It's been two weeks now, I am still half-way through and quite uninterested in finishing it. This isn't because the book is difficult. There's just no story here.    My observations are that Paul Harding is not a storyteller, he's a poet, interested in words, but who can't seem to able to pen a tale capable of keeping a reader interested from the first to the last page. A tale where you cling to the protagonist as if his fate was yours. There are no characters in tinkers, in the sense that I don't feel attached to any of them.    A man lies dying in a hospital bed in the middle of his living room, so the author decides to show us the dying man's memories of life during those last few hours. Instead of painting a clear and passionate story, the author goes on a mad ride on words, which end up suffocating the whole plot, if there's actually one and if there is none, at least the book should've been character-driven to keep the reader pinned. Because the characterization is lame, the author fills this gap with purple prose. It isn't uncommon that he says the same thing in ten different ways within the same sentence.      If you are looking for a novel on how to construct ridiculously long sentences, gain a fair grip on metaphorical language and flowery writing, at the expense of interesting and well developed characters that you feel attached to, then read tinkers. If not, run.      I can live with some of the beauty in the exaggerated language used. But I believe there are way better books out there worth a Pulitzer prize than this one.

In 1961, \\"Milionaire\\" was the premiere film on NBC's brand new \\"Saturday Night at the Movies\\" series.<br /><br />In this amalgam of two Broadway shows, \\"[[ASIN:B000R9COGM The Greeks Had a Word For Them]]\\" and \\"Loco,\\" the trio of Bacall, Grable and Monroe portray golddigging gals who aggressively target wealthy men. At the end, they all wed guys as poor as they are, or so it seems.<br /><br />It's frothy '50s stuff that's hampered at times by the censorship of that era. Example: Monroe must say \\"Men aren't attentive to girls who wear glasses\\" instead of \\"don't make passes at.\\" There's still room for some zingers, such as Bacall's old age barb aimed right at husband Humphrey Bogart: \\"Look at Roosevelt, look at Churchill, look at old fella whats-his-name in [[ASIN:B002TOL4QO THE AFRICAN QUEEN]].<br /><br />Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.<br /><br />(7.0) How to Marry a Millionaire (1953) - Lauren Bacall/Betty Grable/Marilyn Monroe/David Wayne/Rory Calhoun/Cameron Mitchell/Fred Clark/Wiliam Powell (uncredited: Merry Anders/Percy Helton/Philip Van Zandt)

She did so with Twilight, which was a huge smash with teens everywhere. And she does have a good eye for a shot, and several scenes here show. If had to recommend the movie for one thing alone, it would be for the visuals. The look of the film has a gorgeous, lush and colourful palette that made this film worth seeing on the big screen.<br /><br />The film's biggest problem aside from being anti-climatic is that the plot is just... a mangled mess. It reads like a really bad fanfiction. If you thought Tim Burton's Alice In Wonderland was bad... .wait till you get a load of this movie. We have several plot points that come in and suddenly are left do die, one of which includes Father Solomon played by Gary Oldman, who is made to be a crazy bastard type character, and we don't see anything to prove it. To top it all off, it's rife with clich&eacute;s, like the obligatory love triangle, the whodunit, damned protagonist.<br /><br />The actors are a mixed bag. Seyfried does a good job here and has plenty of emotion in her performance. She has plenty of cheesy lines but she does a good job for what she has to work with. Gary Oldman was also great, but that was expected as he always shines with every performance. On the downside, Shiloh Fernandez gives one of the worst performances ever here. He spends the whole movie looking like he wants to punch someone and reads his lines like he's reading them off a paper. And Virginia Madsen just awful here as well, and is over-acting Billy Burke.<br /><br />In short Red Riding Hood is a film that has plenty of promise, but sadly doesn't live up to it. It isn't a bad film by any means, but you are most likely to leave disappointed.ty of promise, but sadly doesn't live up to it. It isn't a bad film by any means, but you are most likely to leave disappointed.
B00475AYJQ|5.0|I have finished The Wise Man's Fear by Patrick Rothfuss.<br /><br />The short review: It was everything I hoped it would be.<br /><br />2011 is filled with promise. There are a number of high-profile releases taking place this year, and The Wise Man's Fear was near the top of my list. I know I am not alone. After the March 2007 release of The Name of the Wind (review HERE), author Patrick Rothfuss gained an immediate growing readership that, in the four years since, has spanned the globe and become a cultish following that even Neil Gaiman would be envious of. In essence, The Name of the Wind is one of those excellent debuts that most people fall in love with, due to one of the most fully realized characters I've read--Kvothe, Arliden's son.<br /><br />Imagine how difficult it has been for those fans, who will have had to patiently wait four years to read The Wise Man's Fear on March 1st.<br /><br />For the purposes of this review, however, the readership of Patrick Rothfuss is one of three parts.<br /><br />The first part of the readership is one that is apparent but rare, like those who haven't watched the original Star Wars trilogy or hate Harry Potter. If you read The Name of the Wind and did not care for it, you will not enjoy The Wise Man's Fear.<br /><br />The second part is one that is more apparent still. If you read The Name of the Wind and loved the entirety of it like your first read of The Hobbit or viewing of The Fellowship of the Ring, you will love the entirety of The Wise Man's Fear.<br /><br />The third part is possibly the hardest to explain because it encompasses both other parts. I am within this part. It is a readership who enjoyed the first book but also thought it had some areas it could have been improved.<br /><br />The Name of the Wind is a fabulous book. As I said in my review, it is also a rare book. The life story of Kvothe is told with brilliant expertise for a first time writer, and it grabs a hold of the imagination and doesn't let go. That said, I felt it could have been tightened up, not just extraneous words throughout the prose but also in the middle of the story when the narrative slowed down quite a bit once Kvothe entered the University.<br /><br />The Wise Man's Fear is a great deal tighter when it comes to its words. Patrick spent four years rewriting it and it shows quite clearly. The additional words that hampered The Name of the Wind a bit are gone here. Each sentence is constructed with nary a word out of place; every paragraph flows smoothly page after page. I think readers will be able to tell the difference.<br /><br />The Wise Man's Fear does still have moments where the narrative slows down to a crawl. Readers within this particular part of three will notice it as I did. It is a large book and while the character development Kvothe goes through is fascinating, real, and tangible--to the point I'd argue he truly becomes a man in this book--it comes at a price. There were four different moments where I wanted the story to pick up and those were the moments I put the book down to work, go for a walk, or check email.<br /><br />Those other tasks didn't last long though. I returned to the book, as enchanted as before, and made my way through the areas I think could have been pruned back some. I was rewarded every time. Rothfuss is truly great at giving the reader a payoff like you can't believe after every lull.<br /><br />In this book, the stakes are even higher for Kvothe. Forced from the University, he takes to the road to find a patron. What he finds is nothing he expected to find. Lovelorn kings. Civilized mercenaries. The inhuman Fae. And the name of the wind.<br /><br />I'll leave it at that. No spoilers here.<br /><br />I sincerely cannot wait to discuss this book with all of you when it is published. I eagerly look forward to the third book in the Kingkiller Chronicle, The Doors of Stone! It can't come quick enough but I'll wait for it patiently because I can see the payoff for the entire trilogy is going to be something truly special.<br /><br />Overall, The Wise Man's Fear is as great a sequel book as we all could have hoped for.<br /><br />Final Verdict: 4 1/2 / 5 starsequel book as we all could have hoped for.    Final Verdict: 4 1/2 / 5 stars

0316666343|1.0|***BIG TIME SPOILERS HERE***    The Lovely Bones is a novel following the Aftermath of the murder of 14 year old Susie Salmon, who watches and narrates our tale from her \\"personal\\" version of heaven where everyone gets what they want, but it's really more of a prison, as they are helpless to intervene with the matters of their friends and family.    Really, as many others said, and I can't stress this enough, the first chapter is pretty much the best chapter in the entire novel. It's interesting, captivating and keeps you on hold with a \\"can't put it down\\" type of feel you just want to know more. After this however, it's a slow trip downhill. One of my problems with this book is that the characters seem very flat and lifeless, and when they did have life, it seemed very contrived and \\"wrong\\" from some reason.    Susie stopped sounding like a 14 year old after chapter 2. By Chapter 3 she used enough prose and description to sound as if she was approaching her sixtieth birthday.  Also, I found it disturbing that \\"Holly\\" an Asian girl, whom Susie meets in heaven, wishes to not have an accent. You would think that one wouldn't carry societal hang-ups in their own personal version of heaven and be proud of whom they are but I guess not.     Lindsey, Susie's younger sister by about two years, Also seemed to possess this disturbing amount of otherworldly maturity for a girl at the age of 12 to find out her older sister has died. I get it, she's smart and snaky, but really, who has that much composure at that young of an age, no matter how much they've been through? The entire scene where she loses her virginity to Samuel seemed unrealistic to me, just the way she handled it. She too, acted as if she was about 42 rather than 12 when the book started, and it doesn't get any better. Also, how many people do you know that have stayed with he same person since they've been 11 years old? And haven't fought once?     For the first half of the book, Susie's younger brother Buckleyis treated more like a houseplant than a character story wise; it's like you're aware he's there, but there's no description of him really and he's dismissed as quickly as he's brought up. It's almost massif the author was afraid to write about a character so young so she skipped him all together until he got a little older. When he does get a little older, he ends up becoming my favorite character and a lot of times, seems like the only sane one in the entire novel. He's also the ONLY one to not take his mother's bullcrap after she abandons them and walks out on the family for almost a decade.    The grandmother was an alcoholic mess/GILF that border lined on a Golden Girls style parody.    The father, I think was one of the most realistic characters of the stories. He has problems letting go of his daughter's death even though years have passed by and everyone else has moved on.  The mother, though. I could not stand. She was about as bad a Bella swan when it comes to Character Depth and maturity. I felt not a single ounce of sympathy for her. She doesn't even seem that sad about the horrific murder of her daughter, more like slightly annoyed. She decide she can't handle the grief and after briefly hooking up and cheating on her husband with the detective working on her daughters case no less; she decides to abandon her two young children and husband in their time of need to run away to California with little reason other than the fact that she was sad over Susie's death.  It was quite annoying to read about and whenever it go to describing the mother I just wanted to skip through it so badly.    Then you have some of Susie's Classmates: Clarissa, Ruth and Ray, the last one being Susie's *almost* boyfriend. Clarissa seems to be the most realistic out of the three. She's a bit of a floozy and while she's sad about her friend's death, she eventually moves on with her life. Ruth, a neurotic sixth sense girl with lesbian tendencies is eerily obsessed with her death despite the fact that Susie Barely knew her. While Susie seems to be happy about this, I found it to be deeply disturbing.    She's basically like Mr. Harvey; a psycho with a crush only she investigates Murders instead of being a murderer. Ray too, while a sympathetic character (his *almost* girlfriend goes missing and gets murdered. Ouch!)  But he too, seems unnaturally preoccupied with Susie's death, to the point where you wonder why he is still angsting about his middle school crush's death when he's in his late teens and early twenties, even. It didn't seem real.     I'll admit the second half of the book went by incredibly slowly and suddenly switched to Susie describing the day by day actions of her family and friends to suddenly skipping 5-10 years down the road. The second half was pretty painful to get through. The only interesting parts ere the ones about Mr. Harvey, the rapist killer of Susie and almost laughably textbook Serial Killer (Thick Glasses, really quiet, fairly weird ,makes DOLLHOUSES for god's sake) and watching him cover his tracks.    And don't even get me started on the ending: It almost made me sick. Mr. Harvey's demise ends in the stupidest way imaginable. He slips on an alluded to icicle and falls down a ravine. How silly. Might as well have him get attacked  by a gang of clowns in a clown car. I understand that Sebold was trying to tell us that not all crimes go unpunished but really, anything else would have been more realistic. I personally would have had him get killed by a bunch of thugs while stalking some inner city girl. On top of that Susie gets her one chance to come down from heaven and uses it not to tell her friend and family how she was, that's she's okay, or where her body was. She uses it to get laid. Which is pretty odd considering she was RAPED and KILLED.    Overall, The Lovely Elbows---oops,I mean Bones, was an utter disappointment and I cannot recommend it. One star.

I mean, honestly... gay people aren't like the way the Cast girls portray the characters.    I'll start off with the fact I am absolutely shocked that this is labeled as a Young Adult novel. If it is truly a Young Adult novel, should I not feel safe giving this book to almost every thirteen year old girl I know, and any younger girl from ten and older whom I find to be mature. The sad fact is, I honestly don't feel like I can do this.     I now wish to move onto the fact that Zoey is not a likable character. Some people argue that a book can't influence girls to act bad, but that depends on how much they actually understand right and wrong about the certain issues in the book and how mature they are to understand the issues. Honestly, I wonder if this book had been published AFTER his death, if people might not have been in an uproar. Actually, I wonder why this issue hasn't been brought up at all.    And then there is the issue of religion. Truth of the matter is, it is poorly handled. The Cast family use the stereotype of Christians being suppressive of other beliefs and they made mistakes on the other religions. They didn't bother one bit to do their research. The reason for this story is to create a wish fulfillment.    And the comparisons to Twilight? Yeah, they are both about vampires and they both have characters who come across as rather shallow, but I for once have to say Twilight is much better written and has better morals then this book, which is saying something considering I don't find Twilight to be a well written book, nor to have good morals and that I think should be understood and explained to girls as a read for enjoyment purposes only.

B001NHZ2KM|5.0|The finest biographical rock documentary, it is negligent not to include this with 'The T.A.M.I. Show', 'Monterey Pop', 'Woodstock', 'Gimme Shelter' and the other documentaries that have achieved legendary status. But I think there is one more thing that needs to come onto DVD to truly understand what The Who meant to their fans.<br /><br />Much more so than other acts, writers discussing The Who would bend over backwards to show that their opinions were not influenced by radio airplay - as a result they proclaimed ad nauseum that everything recorded before 'Tommy' was perfect while everything after was garbage (TKAA even has something to offer that crowd as there are four (!) versions of \\"My Generation\\").<br /><br />Growing up a fan, however, my friends and I would decide what to listen to and buy according to our own instincts about what was exciting and energetic rather than the pretensions or delusions of Rolling Stone writers. This meant of course that among one of rock's mightiest repertoires one album would always be the greatest ('Who's Next') and one song always the greatest - \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\" - the original version a performance so stirring and majestic that it cannot be left off any SINCERE list of the greatest rock songs of all time.<br /><br />But as the song's reputation built throughout the 1970's the live performance of WGFA transformed into something far, far, far beyond a routine rendition. The grandest of grande finales, it became the single greatest moment of anticipation, drama and ecstasy in all of 20th Century music - I personally can't think of anything comparable other than the endings of the greatest Verdi operas. If you were lucky enough to be there when every last fan in a crowd of 20,000, 40,000 or 60,000 raised his hands and yelled YEEEEEEAAAAHHHHHHHH!!!! with Roger at the end of the last synthesizer break, then you knew you were part of a spine-tingling, goose-bumping audience thrill you could experience nowhere else.<br /><br/>All Who fans should be grateful to Jeff Stein for acknowledging the pride of place of WGFA in the Who canon by selecting it as the concluding number. The version here is magnificent, unto itself justifying a five star rating for the DVD. But because it was filmed on a soundstage, there is only the faintest glimmer of the audience dynamics that would help the viewer understand what that song, and indeed what the band, meant to its audience. I'm still hoping that someday there will be a DVD of comparable quality of one of the large scale shows (the Shea Stadium concert comes to mind) so everyone can understand completely why The Who inspired more devotion than any act in the history of rock'n'roll.
