B001KTNW4G|5.0|As with another of his books, Kane and Abel, Jeffery Archer treats his readers to beautifully developed characters in opposition, spicing up descriptions of their early lives with his gift for inserting believable accidents and coincidences that lead to what we now refer to as \\"six degrees of separation\\". The two men in this book, both media kings, will remind anyone of Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Townsend. What is always such a treat when it comes to Archer's work is that nagging suspicion that with his own high flying career as a member of parliment and access to a certain portion of the glitterati, he might actually know something about the real life people that inspire his stories that we don't. It is also a well researched look into the world of news production, the fourth estate, including edifying behind-the-scenes- information. Though not as popular today, well worth reading.
0375842209|5.0|\\"The door was opened and shut, and a figure was crouched over him.  The hand splashed at the cold waves of his clothes and the grimy currents beneath.  A voice came down, behind it.\\"  And so I let the Book Thief speak for itself.  This short quote speaks volumes about Markus Zusak's debut novel.  This sentence is heavy with the novel's characteristic metaphoric imagery and subtly dark undertone.  The Book Thief is a modern Bildungsroman.  However, unlike many books in which the story is centered solely on the growth of a protagonist, the Book Thief's growing maturity serves rather as a reflection of the world around her.  The main character, Liesel Meminger, is a young girl in Germany during World War II and the Holocaust.  We meet her just as she witnesses the death of her younger brother, and just before she and her mother part ways, Liesel to remain with foster parents in the town of Molching.  Despite these unfortunate circumstances, Liesel retains the typical innocence of youth, with its fears, triumphs, and simple pleasures.  It is not long, though, before she is awakened to the troubles of the world by the quiet arrival of a man at her new home.  This man, whom she would come to know as Max, is a Jew, and he lives in her basement.     The Book Thief is wonder of modern literature.  In a time of Twilights, Harry Potters, and other popular pulp fiction, The Book Thief stands as a monument to what a book in the 21st century can be.  What makes Marcus Zusak's book so exceptional is the unique way he has chosen to write the story.  The first distinctive aspect of The Book Thief, and the one most immediately obvious, is the identity of its narrator: Death.  Indeed, it is the Grim Reaper himself who introduces Liesel's tale and will act as a constant companion and commentator for the reader.  One may immediately assume that they are surely embarking upon a grim read when they discover this fact.  Honestly, I can't imagine who wouldn't: a novel set in Nazi Germany narrated by Death himself, undoubtedly witness to theJewish genocide we know is to come.  However, as becomes apparent in the first few pages, Death is actually rather sympathetic, self-effacing, and jaded.  It is not only his ironic disposition that gives the book a distinguishing flair, but the manner in which he allows the story to unfold.  He does not reveal events in a typical manner, and perhaps this is an intentional reminder by the author that this is not your typical narrator.  Death's world-weary attitude is epitomized in this passage, one that follows Death's premature divulgence of an important character's death : \\"Of course, I'm being rude.  I'm spoiling the ending, not only of the entire book, but of this particular piece of it.  I have given you two events in advance, because I don't have much interest in building mystery.  Mystery bores me.  It chores me.  I know what happens and so do you.  It's the machinations that wheel us there that aggravate, perplex, interest, and astound me.\\"  Death provides a unique omniscient perspective blurring the line between participatory character and narrator.     It is not only how the book is written that sets it apart and makes it memorable, it also the words with which it is written that leave a lasting impression in the reader's mind.  The language.  Markus Zusak has subtly woven stunning imagery into The Book Thief.  These moments are not a Dickens-esque orgy of detail, but instead careful, crafted instances of literary innovation.  Zusak treats these moments as a master poet would, carefully choosing each word for maximum effect.  The irony is that while the amount of words may seem spartan, the vivid scenes they conjure are anything but.  Zusak presents shimmering triumphs of diction and syntax, proving again and again that all it takes is the right words.  \\"The last time I saw her was red. The sky was like soup, boiling and stirring. In some places it was burned. There were black crumbs and pepper, streaked across the redness.\\"  This is a Zusakian depiction of a town post-bombing.  Metaphors and similes are apparent and yet it goes far beyond the simple use of such stylistic tools.  It is the way in which a scene can be delivered with language seemingly so far removed from the subject matter and yet still be painted more vividly than one would have thought possible.     The Book Thief is certainly not the first World War II novel to be written, nor will it be the last.  Neither is it the first work in the genre to discuss the Nazi oppression of Jews and the abuse which the members of the Jewish faith suffered.  In fact, it is this abundance that causes so many books which follow classics like Night by Elie Wiesel to fail to distinguish themselves.  Markus Zusak avoids falling into this trap by approaching familiar subject matter innovatively and thus carving his own place in the overburdened genre.  Unlike many other books, both fiction and nonfiction, The Book Thief does not rely solely on \\"shock factors\\" to make its message meaningful and lasting.  Indeed, where even Night is most memorable for the unprecedented cruelty and degradation it tells of, Zusak takes a different route.  He incorporates the same issues of the Second World War in a much subtler manner, making his narrative one with sweetness, adventure, and even humor.  The differences go beyond even this.  The protagonist of the book, as you now know, is a German girl guilty of no Jewish heritage.  Zusak seems to have chosen to examine the Holocaust not through an abused Jewish lens, but through the eyes of a child on the outside.  And this makes all the difference.  One can never truly rely on the accuracy of an account given by someone on whom crimes are being perpetrated.  They will always see the perpetrators as evil.  Whereas the young Liesel has not yet formed preconceptions of good and evil, she has neither been hurt by Nazis nor indoctrinated into their ideology.  Thus, it is the mind of a child that truly makes this tale believable.     At the risk of hyperbole, I would call The Book Thief a modern classic.  A book becomes a classic when it does something innovative or represents a supremely masterful example of its genre.  I feel that Markus Zusak has created something that succeeds on both fronts.
0743289692|5.0|Infidel is an amazing book.  It is the best autobiography I have ever read.  It is extremely well written and one of the most informative books I have ever found.  I couldn't put it down.  It should be read by everyone who cares about what is happening in America and in the world today.  As the story of a woman growing up within the religion of Islam, it describes the terrible way that religion treats women.  It clearly shows the danger that Islam is to freedom in Africa, Holland, the rest of Europe and in America.

You have a quest to finish (like \\"get to room X and kill the bad guy\\") and dozens of bad guys in the way.<br /><br />Each player is on the same side and has a set of skills vital to the success of the mission. Everyone has a ton of fun.<br /><br />Lastly, I should mention that the creatures generally have 1 or 2 or 3 hit points, not 40 or 80 or 200. So the math is easier and the game plays faster than standard DnD encounters.<br /><br />If you want to have some hack-n-slash fun with a board game, then get this today. You won't regret it.

B00368Q3UY|5.0|Very impressive speaker with intriguing design. What I received from package was a USB cable for charging and transferring files to the sd card, a nice looking blue earphone, a pouch for carrying, and the speaker itself along with the sd card already inserted inside.    PRO:  -The micro sd card included works well also. No problem arises there.   -The sound quality is quite crisp for its size. The loudness is immense.   -The blue earphone that came with it has surprisingly nice sound quality. Earphones came with the main product in general usually has crappy sound quality. But this one really sounds very clear. The only thing missing in it is some bass, but who am I to complain with something free and awesome like that?  -Battery life is definitely an attraction on the Happy. I let it on at full charge with decent volume level that can fill the room. Without turning it off, I received a kick-a$$ 12.5 hours of continuous playback. It's difficult to tell what the volume level was but I'd have to guess at about 1/3 full volume. Of course it would drain more power if it sets at higher volume.    CON:  I think this could be a flaw in the Happy since other reviews have also mentioned this. When I turn it on, the Happy immediately plays the song at MAX volume. This can be very obnoxious and disruptive to other people if you're in a quiet place. Even so, I have found a very simple tricks that might help against this annoyance:    -First, you notice when you turn it on, the LED indicator is immediately turned purple(this means it's at full power or enough power to play) for a second or two. Then it quickly turns to red for about 3sec before the red is blinking. The moment the red is blinking it starts to play at max volume. And this is what I suggest if you dont want to experience the full volume at the start: When the LED turns to red, quickly press the mute button before it has the chance to blink. Turn the volume down by holding it for about 7sec. before letting go. Thenyou can press the mute again to hear where you're at.    Besides the max volume blast at the start, it doesn't seem to have any other flaw.    I also have the x-mini II speaker and the Happy can extend upward more, so maybe more bass than the x-mini II? Cant really tell the difference but it should add a bit more bass nonetheless.

0316044695|5.0|This book is so well-written that it reads like a novel. Mr. Luttrel does an amazing job of describing the rigorous training required before someone can become a Navy SEAL. Just knowing that we have special forces who possess the skills that this elite group does made me so proud of our country and our military. The book is very balanced as far as describing the training experience and the incident that occurred in Afghanistan, costing the lives of his comrades and the additional lives of the SEALs and Army personnel who responded to the urgent call for help sent out by the team leader. Mr. Luttrell gives a vivid description of how the four-man team dropped into the country, acccomplished their mission, and were well on their way to the pick-up point when they encountered a couple of \\"goat-herders\\". Not being able to discern whether these goat-herders were \\"friendlies\\" or not, the four of them voted as to whether they should kill them or not. The moral dilemna facing them resulted in the decision to do what was \\"right\\" and let them go. Unfortunately, these men were not friendlies and immediately rounded up insurgents to seek and kill the Americans. The trials that the group of SEALs endured were superheroic, and Marcus's survival was a miracle. I majored in history, taught it, and still study it, so I read many war books, and I have to say that this book is one of the very best ones I have read on any war. Marcus Luttrell is an incredible human being, dedicated to his country and to his comrades. He is so thorough in relating the events of the nightmare that he endured that he makes sure to credit the tribal chief and the villagers who saved his life by prohibiting the Taliban from harming him by pointing out to them that they would not allow them to violate the true laws of the Muslim people. This book is an eye-opener in so many ways; it shows the rigorous training and testing required to become a SEAL, the dedication, loyalty, and brotherhood of this elite fighting force, and shows that not all Muslims are anti-American, but truly live by real Muslim laws which require that once a village takes a stranger in, he becomes their responsiblity to nurture and protect. If this book was a movie, it would be one where everyone would be sitting on the edge of his seat. This story is incredible in every possible way and is so well-written that it is as difficult for the reader to put down as a mystery/thriller.

So who is the werewolf, and does anyone in the audience actually care?<br /><br />Don't worry, Team Jacob -- \\"Red Riding Hood\\" is all about the hot maybe-werewolf guy taking center stage. Catherine Hardwicke tosses aside the possibilities of a \\"dark\\" psychosexual retelling of a fairy tale, mainly so she can try to reel in all the screeching hormone-addled tweenagers who rushed to see her last gothic romance.<br /><br />The problem is, \\"Twilight\\" was boring. 1932907009|3.0|As promised, this is an easy-to-read, to-the-point book of screenwriting advice. It is by no means the LAST book on screenwriting one will need, but it offers a non-academic, writer-to-writer perspective on the nuts and bolts of writing a screenplay--in particular, a GOOD screenplay that will be bought.<br /><br />Unfortunately, that's the sole goal presented by Snyder: sell it. He does offer detailed directions and convenient schematics to help you write a screenplay that no one will laugh at, that doesn't suffer from the plot and character problems that plague American cinema, and he does so to help you have your screenplay sold and produced. In general, this is helpful, and his rules and lists, signs of a huge film buff, are entertaining and enlightening. But the arrogance with which he presents these \\"rules\\" (his main purpose in writing the book, he admits, is to take credit for these golden laws), his tendency to assume his reader shares all his movie preferences, and his misspelling of actor's and director's names all severely hurt his credibility as both a writer and a mentor.<br /><br />In the process of delineating good screenplays from bad ones, or explaining storytelling techniques, he arbitrarily assigns value to his movie examples depending on his current case. In one chapter, \\"good\\" means the movie follows his rules, \\"bad\\" means it doesn't--whether or not the movie was critically well-received. In the next, \\"good\\" means critically well-received, and \\"bad\\" means crappy writing that happened to do well at the box office. Often, his otherwise solid advice drowns in these discussions, and we finish a chapter with Snyder picking a fight with his reader while encouraging them to finish the book before they begin writing. (?!)<br /><br />Also disturbing is that Snyder equates box office success to artistic success, then trashes box office hits for their writing problems. He scoffs at unconventional storytelling (his seething hatred for \\"Memento\\" practically burns the page) and primarily uses comedies as examples, while dismissing films that focus on character or are plot-heavy (I'd like to see him try to explain \\"Inception's\\" success despite it breaking all his rules!).<br /><br />One imagines that Snyder has created a list of movies he likes, and movies he doesn't like, and expects all intelligent moviegoers and screenwriters have those same lists. And one has to wonder if his goal is really to help you write your screenplay, or to convert you to his approach to movies and screenwriting. Either way, his jealousy of more skilled screenwriters and his disdain for any movie made for the sake of art, not money, is both apparent and off-putting. I would rather read a screenwriting book that assumed its readers wanted to make money AND art, to have box office success AND awards. Or at least present the challenges to screenwriting in a way that didn't favor comedy writers, or help churn out more of the same crap that pollutes cinema. Mr. Snyder, you seem interested in sparing us from crappy movies...maybe in your next edition you should encourage a little more rule-breaking. That way lies real cinematic art.rily uses comedies as examples, while dismissing films that focus on character or are plot-heavy (I'd like to see him try to explain \\"Inception's\\" success despite it breaking all his rules!).    One imagines that Snyder has created a list of movies he likes, and movies he doesn't like, and expects all intelligent moviegoers and screenwriters have those same lists. And one has to wonder if his goal is really to help you write your screenplay, or to convert you to his approach to movies and screenwriting. Either way, his jealousy of more skilled screenwriters and his disdain for any movie made for the sake of art, not money, is both apparent and off-putting. I would rather read a screenwriting book that assumed its readers wanted to make money AND art, to have box office success AND awards. Or at least present the challenges to screenwriting in a way that didn't favor comedy writers, or help churn out more of the same crap that pollutes cinema. Mr. Snyder, you seem interested in sparing us from crappy movies...maybe in your next edition you should encourage a little more rule-breaking. That way lies real cinematic art.
0316017922|4.0|You have read the stories about successful people - now it is time to read the story of success.    out-li-er \noun  1: something that is situated away from or classed differently from a main or related body  2: a statistical observance that is markedly different in value from others is the sample      A year after publication Malcolm Gladwell's book Outliers was still on dozens of best seller lists. Every airport book kiosk travelers passed by over the Thanksgiving holiday held Outliers and I suspect the same will be true for Christmas travelers as well. What is it about the story of success that has everyone \\"wanting to know?\\"      Perhaps our obsession with books about successful people is that we hope by reading their stories, some of their success will some how rub off on us. Self made millionaires - we want to be one. An overnight success, we dream of the possibilities.  Someone who \\"pulled themselves up by their own bootstraps...\\" we secretly think we have the chutzpah to pull it off.  But are these \\"true stories\\" real?    The hypothesis of Outliers is contrary to every overnight success fantasy you have ever heard or hoped for. For Gladwell there are no self made men or women and no one pulls themselves up by their own bootstraps, not just because it's a physical impossibility but because success is a group endeavor.    Beginning with hockey stars in Canada and ending with the very personal story of his grandmother Daisy in Jamaica, Gladwell takes us literally around the world and through time looking at success stories.  In between these you will enjoy his foray into the lives of Microsoft mogul Bill Gates and the heart throbs of the 60s - The Beatles. The things that hold these stories together are the circumstances and contributions of the people around the outliers (the successes); they were in the right place at the right time with the support of the right people.    When I first read Outliers I was disturbed at the notion that success is so utterly dependent upon community and circumstance.  I have always believed the \\"it takes a village to raise a child\\" concept, but still at heart I wanted to believe that someone completely disadvantaged by circumstance and birth could change their fortunes.  Gladwell completely destroys this myth so you may wonder why the book is still so successful.  People don't like having their hopes and dreams dashed, unless, that is, they are replaced with something better.  Gladwell does give us something better.  In an interview about the book he contends, \\"When outliers become outliers it is not just because of their own efforts. It's because of the contributions of lots of different people and lots of different circumstances-- and that means that we, as a society, have more control about who succeeds--and how many of us succeed--than we think. That's an amazingly hopeful and uplifting idea.\\"  We as a society can control how we enable more people to succeed!  The most astonishing example of this in the book is the chapter about airplane crashes caused by culture. Yes, you read that right - but to find how they got that information from the black boxes you'll have to read the book! When the cultural problem was identified the corporations went to work retraining key people to act differently. It was expensive work.  It met with heavy resistance, but it saved lives.  Is that more hopeful than a dream about bootstraps?  This book reviewer says, \\"Yes!\\"

0393338827|2.0|Could have done without this book.  It's the story of a fair amount of ignorance, malfeasance, negligence, and outright fraud on Wall Street in conjunction with a massive market meltdown.  The basic contours of the story are probably well enough understood by most from reading papers and magazines; only if you are interested in breathless descriptions of Wall Street heroes (and anti-heroes) operating on the basis of naked greed in a world of inside-baseball finance would you find this book exciting.  Yes, the subprime fiasco reached all the way through the fabric of American society, but reading about every little move these little wizzes made does not help to derive any greater moral from the story than we already have.  To his credit, the author does recognize repeatedly what a con job this was as to ordinary Americans.  Otherwise, this is plain old business history for a select group of folks.  Most galling was the author's riff on how second-rate the ratings company guys were - cheap ties, cheap suits, look like bureaucrats, make only \\"high five figures\\", etcetera.  You can probably do without this book unless you are either a complete insider, or totally ignorant as to what happened in the meltdown.  For the rest of us, your conclusions about the subprime crisis probably won't be improved (either way) by this book.
0756404738|3.0|To understand this review, know that Name of the Wind (book one in this story) is one of my top 3 books of all time, along side George R. R. Martin's Game of Thrones. Tolkien is a pulp hack beside these works. The two parts from Name of the Wind where (spoiler alert for Name of the Wind:) Kvothe saved the girl from flames in the fishery and played the lute minus a string to earn his pipes will stick with me for decades.(end of spoiler) THIS BOOK, HOWEVER, has NO SUCH SCENES. It is 1000 pages akin to a shallow pool. Just when a certain story begins to take shape and become interesting, he ends it and moves on to another point in Kvothe's life. The writing is as strong as the first book, it's just that the stories are disjointed and brief. The only thing connecting them is that they are all Kvothe's past experiences. If you've ever read a collection of short stories, you'll know the feeling. You can't tell a 5-star story in 25-pages. Jamming twenty decent ministories together in a single book cannot make it somehow collectively better. This book should have been 3 or 4 separate books each giving time to create the richness I appreciated before. A 5-star story makes a grown man laugh and cry when he reads it. It's not a bad book, but it's light-years away from the first one. The disappointment factor alone is worth the loss of a star. As far as the ending, the only way I could tell the book was done was because there were no more pages to turn. It stunk. No cliffhanger, no real closure, no unification of the disjointed stories, squat. Just some kind of weak acknowledgement that he has to stop this trainwreck at some point. It might be some kind of foundation for the next book... not really to be enjoyed itself. Only time will tell I suppose. Is it worth the price and a good read? Yes. Will it satisfy your appetite for more Name of the Wind? ABSOLUTELY NOT. Should you just put it in your queue for two years till the next one comes out? I would.

B0034G4ORC|3.0|Movie opens with a platoon of marines out of Camp Pendleton flying into the heat of battle over LA as the alien invasion takes shape.  A flashback of twenty-four hours gives you the backstories on most of the featured characters right up until the action starts.  The aliens quickly take the coastlines and move inland quickly.  The decision is made to draw a line inland and use fighter planes to bomb out the alien ground troops, believing they lack airpower.  Staff Sgt. Nantz (Aaron Eckhardt) leads his unit into the bombed out streets of the city to rescue civilians holed up in a police station before the strafing begins.  But the aliens soon reveal their aerial strength, negating the military's advantage and hastening the takeover of the city.  Their numbers down, Nantz must both protect the civilians and reach a safe point before they're overcome by the invaders.  In the midst of a last ditch evacuation, Nantz discovers the location of the alien's command center and leads his team in a desperate strike to cripple their forces.<br /><br />As far as the action goes- Note to Hollywood: get rid of that 'Shaky-Cam' garbage!  What's the point of a battle when you can't even tell what the hell's happening?  (Ok, they're shooting- wait, what was that?  Who got hit?  Where'd those come from... and how did he get killed?)  It's not edgy, it's not gritty and it's not dramatic- it's a stupid gimmick to fudge a fight scene... and it doesn't even do that anymore.  Xbox has clearer shootouts than this.  There's lots of bodies, bullets and things that get blowed up good- everything you want in an alien invasion/war movie.  Problem is they also drown out the dialog- half the time you can't even hear what they're saying over the gunfire and whatnot.  But the images of LA burning look pretty good, especially at night, and give a great sense of the grimness of the situation.<br /><br />The script gets pretty silly at times, even for an action flick.  Much was made of the whole 'aliens have been spying upon us for decades' plot, but it never materializes.  They land and they kill, with barely a handwave as to why (we got water, lots of water).  The bulk of the movie centers upon the platoon's street engagements with the aliens as they struggle to reach the safe haven of the base. But whether you've served in the military or just seen a whole bunch of movies, there's some things that don't require both hands and a map to figure out: Why would you think the aliens don't have airpower when they just landed from outer space?  Hey guys- where would you put a command center to protect it if you were invading- underground, you say?  Wow.  Dude- how do we take out the Enemy Command Ship?  By firing only one missile at a time instead of unloading everything we got on that sucker so we can milk this a little longer?  Riiight.<br /><br />Characters are straight out of the cereal box, with only a few brief deviations.  You'd think for all the time spent building them up at the beginning you might get some- nope.  The moments that are supposed to tug at your heart strings and inspire you a little, don't.  With a nearly full house there were no cheers, jeers or anything.  Plus you can pretty much tell which ones have the red-shirts on.<br /><br />'Battle: LA' is nothing if not earnest, but you won't be too impressed by any of it.  But it's good for tossing down some popcorn and jujubees.spying upon us for decades' plot, but it never materializes. Plus you can pretty much tell which ones have the red-shirts on.    'Battle: LA' is nothing if not earnest, but you won't be too impressed by any of it. When I re-read \\"Jane Eyre\\" (and I've only re-read it umpteen-zillion times and counting), I see Dalton as Rochester.  He and Welles share ownership of this part.<br /><br />Zelah Clarke makes a very effective Jane, and the rest of the cast does a creditable job, but this movie belongs to Timothy Dalton. Young Jane was supposed to be small and thin but this young lady, although she is a fairly good actress, looked like she could go up against Mia Hamm in a soccer match and give her a run for her money.<br /><br />However, this is a minor cavil.  The movie is a fine adaptation of Bronte's best-loved book.  Even if you're not into Bronte, see it for Dalton.<br /><br />Judy Lind
B004C4IKCU|5.0|Like \\"From Elvis in Memphis\\" \\"Onstage,\\" \\"Elvis Country\\" and a handful of others, this is, indeed, one the King's best.  Which is merely restating what has already been said by dozens of others.  The only important thing to add is that Bill Holdship (who actually worked as a music critic, for \\"Creem\\", for a short while), dropped the ball in summing up the album.  No hits?  \\"Are You Lonesome Tonight?\\" was a number one hit for Elvis -- it stayed in that postion on \\"Billboard\\" for six weeks!  Not to mention, \\"Stuck on You,\\" \\"It's Now or Never,\\" and \\"Surrender,\\" all number one hits.  And while \\"Reconsider Baby\\" is, indeed, one of the King's bluesiest (although \\"Mess of Blues\\" ain't bad either), he actually managed to return to blues form with an extended version of \\"Merry Christmas Baby\\" (not on this album) that has to be heard to be believed.<br /><br />The second disc in this extended version of the classic \\"Elvis is Back!\\" reissue, includes tracks that were either included on a couple of so-so releases after this album or merely released as singles or EPs (they used to do that waaay back when).<br />\\"Good Luck Charm\\" is the only number one hit on this disc, but that doesn't dampen the thrill of numbers like \\"Little Sister\\", (\\"Marie's the Name of)His Latest Flame\\", \\"I Slipped, I Stumbled I Fell\\", and \\"Feel So Bad\\" (yet another jamming, bluesy piece of music that proves Elvis himselvis had it in his blood).  Too bad whoever put the disc together didn't think to include tracks like \\"Return to Sender\\" (which was relegated to movie album status back in the day) and a cover of Chuck Berry's \\"Memphis, Tennesse\\" that reveals Presley's genius at musical arrangement (Johnny Rivers liked the demo tape of \\"Memphis...\\" that Elvis shared with him so much that he stole the arrangment -- with it's absolutely rocking N rollicking, double drum intro -- and had a top ten hit before Presley could release his cut). All-in-all: a five Star classic, and a must for any true music lover!

B004FGMV0W|5.0|Since the beginning of her career in 2002, Avril has shown the amazing artist she is. Over the years, Avril has proven how much you can get when you do it with love and hard work.    Every album of Avril has its own mark, its own personality. And I really like all of them. But, I have to admit that after The Best Damn Thing I was afraid of never being able to see a truly improvement in Avril's music. So, when I first heard about Goodbye Lullaby I held in Avril's promise that the album would be sincere, honest and that the main point would be her voice.     The Best Damn Thing was fun, but we barely can see Avril's incredible vocal capacity, lost in the middle of crazy drums and loud guitars. Avril needed to move on, and that's what she did on Goodbye Lullaby.    I see people saying that it's boring ballads' album - and it's not true. Not at all. This record is showing Avril as herself, not the dark Avril or the bratty Avril or the rebel from Let Go. It's just Avril, stripped down, finally talking about her deepest feelings, about her flaws, showing her softer side and showing that she cares about everyone she loves.    Goodbye Lullaby is the proof that Avril is a true artist, not only because she's a singer or a designer, but because she has the gift of turn emotions into music. I really recommend this album if you want to know what's inside the heart of the icon of a generation, the girl that came from a small town in Canada and did and still does the music that gives the support and strenght to move on to thousands of people around the world.

038572179X|4.0|This is a hard one for me because I absolutely loved the book until the end, which actually left me MAD. This book also has this quality I like so much in good books - it forces you to think differently, look at life from different angles, and it just works the magic that great writing can do.  I like how we're led to feel so much anger and hatred at Breony - and then we're thrown into Robbie's war stories, all the killing, selfishness and baseness of mankind that war brings out, and then he has the realization, aren't we all guilty?  I thought some parts of the plot were cheesy and undeveloped, but the writing style was so engaging and the overall plot was so suspenseful that I just read past them and still enjoyed the book tremendously.      And then I got to the end, the last chapter, and was literally like, WTF.  I guess it's sort of like, going to a great restaurant and eating great food, but the dessert left you with food poisoning.  You think about your experience at the restaurant and you think what a great appetizer and entree but then you get sick again thinking about the food poisoning the dessert gave you.  Loved the food but just can't get past the dessert.  Don't know if I would go back again.  Still mad that the dessert ruined what could've been a really exceptional experience. 1594202842|4.0|Many Westerners would probably express horror at Amy Chua's parenting style. But that's why one has to admire her book at least a little. She doesn't invent a rosy picture for the reader, and she deliberately describes herself doing things that she surely knew would be condemned by readers. She describes many occasions when her children succeed, but the book mostly focuses on the agonizing day-to-day struggle, her perpetual confrontation with her children, her endless organizational work, and the ultimate emotional toll that her determination takes on everyone. In her defense, it doesn't seem like she had much fun, either.    I myself was frequently horrified. For example, I do not believe that one should ever refer to one's children as \\"garbage,\\" even if this does motivate them to succeed (and I do believe that it could). This has nothing to do with believing in \\"self-esteem.\\" I just think that words mean things -- if I ever did call somebody \\"garbage,\\" I would do so expecting to become their sworn enemy for life. If your children regard you in that manner, I imagine it would be small consolation to have them do so while reciting at Carnegie Hall.    At the same time, parts of this book were bizarrely liberating. There is a horrific scene where the family goes to a restaurant to celebrate Chua's birthday, the children present her with homemade cards, and Chua demonstratively \\"rejects\\" them because they didn't put enough effort into the task. I never thought anyone would actually do this. If I had read this scene in a work of fiction, I would have thought that it was a brilliant literary invention, a daring dramatic device. Chua did it for real. Before you rush to condemn her, think: all ye tired, overworked parents, haven't you ever felt disappointed when your child spends less than thirty seconds on a token gesture of appreciation? Why, you think, can't they care about you just for one day out of the year? Haven't you ever wanted to reproach them for it? Well, thanks to Amy Chua, you can! And, if her account is to be believed, it even works!    Yet, at other times, it gets to be too much. Chua says, in this book and in her original Wall Street Journal essay: \\"And when Chinese kids do excel, there is plenty of ego-inflating parental praise lavished in the privacy of the home.\\" The funny thing is, this statement is made as an aside, in parentheses. The book does not give a single specific example of such praise, as opposed to the many specific examples it gives of insults and demands. It does mention that Chua used to cuddle with her younger daughter, laughing and talking about music, but that's not quite the same thing, and anyway, even this is only mentioned vaguely, with no specifics. I see the stick, but where's the carrot? Where's the positive reinforcement? Maybe the editors removed it, thinking that conflict and confrontation would sell better.    Even more perplexing is Chua's apparent lack of any over-arching goal or purpose. She gets lost in the minutiae of each daily practice session, and thinks about as far ahead as next week's recital. But when you make your kids practice the violin for FIVE HOURS every day, you've got to have some idea as to why. Maybe you really want them to become famous professional violinists. Maybe you view this as a way for them to attract and get married to billionaires. Maybe you genuinely want them to develop a deep love and understanding of music, or maybe you just want them to feel indebted to you so they take care of you when you get old. Some of these reasons might be better than others, but each one is a plan. Chua seems to have none; her main reason for doing all these things is because doing so is \\"Chinese,\\" as if that were enough to explain everything. There's also the need to show up all the other parents, but really now, going to Carnegie Hall in order to be the top student at your school is like using a sledgehammer to crack a walnut. There are also plenty of other ways to getinto Ivy League schools, if that's the goal.    When I first heard about this book, I thought it might be some kind of proud paean to Chinese nationalism. It is nothing like that. In fact, it seems oddly confused on matters of identity. Both daughters are forced to study Mandarin on a daily basis, but they both have trouble viewing themselves as \\"Chinese.\\" There is little connecting them to Chinese culture or history. They only have their grandparents. In fact, Chua herself seems to have no connection to her family history other than her own parents, and her praise for their parenting style. Considering how much she dreaded the influence of Western culture on her children, I would have thought that she'd tell them more about their illustrious ancestors. Instead, she uses herself as an example, and tells them about how she struggled to get a job at Yale. That's a bit less...epic.    So, I'm glad that the book was written, and I think it offers a lot of food for thought. But it didn't answer my question of \\"Why?\\" It seems to me that, if you want somebody to perform amazing feats, you should inspire them with an equally transcendent goal.

B003EYVXUU|4.0|It's rare when a Hollywood remake of a widely acclaimed foreign film is as good as the original.  (Just look at what happened to THE VANISHING!) I usually hate vampire films for a lot of reasons but I love this moody, atmospheric dream that treats desire and alienation with a delicacy that makes real the sacrifices we choose to make for even fleeting intimacy.  Set in Los Alamos, Colorado -- a community with the highest IQ per capita -- the story has a bullied, frail 12-year-old Owen (Kodi Smit-McPhee) befriending his strange next-door neighbor, Abby (a terrific Chloe Moretz from KICK ASS).  Their outcast bond fortifies Owen to stand up to the bullies.  But when Owen confirms his suspicions that Chloe has a big secret, it's too late; his fate is sealed.  This beautifully acted, visually rich, stunning and tragic love story is perfect in almost every way.  Sadly, it was little seen in theaters and deserves to be rediscovered for home video.  The always fine Richard Jenkins co-stars.

1151097764|3.0|The Bonfire of the Vanities by Tom Wolfe is an entertaining book that earns the label of a \\"page-turner\\" through Wolfe's quality prose and ability to showcase the quirky parts of his characters. It's a good story with big implications, seen from the eyes of a handful of different New Yorkers. The best I can give this novel is good, but not great. It has good scenes and good subject matter, but never quite hits what it set out to.     Wolfe gives you a taste of a lot of interesting things and characters that never get expanded on. When you read the two scenes with Bacon (Al Sharpton-lite) you're captivated by him, but he hardly appears otherwise except for somebody mentioning how terrible he is. We meet the judge Kovitsky early on and he's equally interesting, and he goes unheard of until the climax in which he's supposed to be the crux of the finale. We don't find out that Sherman was once an idealist who wasn't consumed by money and social status until it's way too late to care. Sherman's turn from a wimpy yuppie into an \\"animal\\" at the end came off really lame. So now he isn't afraid to lie...wait, hasn't he already lied to everybody he's encountered up to this point?      Wolfe can craft a line with the best of them though, and his humor and descriptive ability usually keeps his stuff afloat when he lacks in other departments. One of the best parts of the book was the dichotomy between Kramer and the women he lusted after. When he was staring down Maria as they interviewed her and his inner dialogue hinted that she might want him, and then we find out that she thought he was a creep was a beautiful notion about how a lot of men think and women's reaction to that. Also when he's rambling to The Girl With the Brown Lipstick about the trial and he thinks she's enthralled with every aspect of it, come to find out at the end of the scene she thinks he's a typical New York male that only talks about themselves. Subtle nuances like this made the book worthwhile despitebeing bashed over the head with the fact that Jews, Italians, Blacks, Irish, rich people and poor people are different. Wolfe also made it a point to note that everybody who worked for the justice system was bald or balding.     I would have liked to have seen the story go to trial and seen Killian and Kramer going at it with Kovitsky playing mediator. I wanted to see Sherman watch Maria testify under oath and I wanted resolution. I guess I can't fault Wolfe for his ending though, because it's his story and that's how he chose to write it. I can say though that the ending felt like a cop-out and a let down. The book was worth reading and a good addition to the Tom Wolfe canon, but not his best work.

This album isn't an extension of 'Under My Skin', it's more a celebration of her musical capabilities--while she doesn't stray into experimental territory or do anything really unlike her, she does do well to stretch herself.  I compare Avril Lavigne's work on 'Goodbye Lullaby' to The Offspring, who sounded much the same across three albums and then suddenly dropped 'Americana' on the world and surprised everybody.<br /><br />Lavigne still has that sassiness about her:  What the Hell is the obvious song, but she also does a good job of laying down the law in \\"Push\\", a song about relationships.  She uses \\"Wish You Were Here\\" to hearken back to her 'Alanis Morissette soundalike' days, then \\"Stop Standing There\\" seems more Radio Disney friendly.  I'm expecting my pre-teen daughter will love this one:  it's an excellent showcase of her vocals, where the instrumentation drops to the background.<br /><br />\\"I Love You\\" should have been released in February - it's a sweet love song and it comes from her young heart. \\"Everybody Hurts\\" is the kind of 'It's okay--we all have that happen' song that makes me think this is the direction Miley Cyrus should have gone in.  As the album winds to a close, you have some softer musical tunes:  \\"4 Real\\" is acoustic with an easy percussion beat, \\"Goodbye\\" and \\"Remember When\\" are heavily piano-driven, and Goodbye ends the album in a lovely way with just strings and her voice.<br /><br />Musically, \\"Goodbye Lullaby\\" is a four-star album--what gives it that last kick into 5-star territory is the production.  Guitar and drum parts are really well balanced, passages with string instruments or piano mesh evenly with Avril Lavigne's voice, and everything really just comes across as well mixed.<br /><br />If you're familiar with Avril Lavigne's earlier work, see this as her next step forward, a good step with confident stride to it.  If you're new to Lavigne and like pop music and female vocalists, you're guaranteed to find something you like.<br /><br />This review is for the explicit MP3 version of the album (and yes, you may be reading this in another flavor of \\"Goodbye Lullaby\\" - Amazon does that sometimes). The collector's edition of the album adds acoustic versions of her vocally-challenging song 'Alice' (from the recent Alice in Wonderland film), 'What the Hell', 'Push', and 'Wish You Were Here'. 0691142165|4.0|This Time is Different is not quite what I expected when I picked it up.  First, it has a bare minimum of qualitative information and really focuses on the quantitative history of debt defaults, banking crises, and inflation crises.  As one friend told me, it is really a book of really interesting tables.  Second, the \\"this time\\" of the title does not refer to recessions or crises but actually the events leading up to them.  The book does not argue that the \\"Great Recession,\\" or what it calls the second great contraction, is not one of the larger, farther reaching recessions of modern history just that the events leading up to it are wholly predictable.    Those surprises are not necessarily drawbacks, but others picking the book up should realize that.  I still learned a lot from the book including about the depth and breadth of historical crises throughout the world, the similarities among crises, and some more details such as the different treatment of domestic and external debt.  Debt is also what makes the book continue to hold great relevance as the financial crisis fades from view but the U.S. still grapples with large annual deficits and continued long term debt.

1439102813|5.0|Ever know someone with Alzheimer's and wonder what they are thinking?  Still Alice by Lisa Genova is a brilliant novel that shares what it is like to have Alzheimer's from the point of view of one who actually has it!  Most stories about people with Alzheimer's are told from the caretaker's point of view.  Still Alice lets the reader inside the mind of the person afflicted with this degenerative disease which has no cure.  Alice is only 50 and already has some symptoms of dementia.  She is a college professor at Harvard, the wife of a scientist and mother of three grown children.  This is a story about a family and how the mother with Alzheimer's feels as she discovers she is losing her memory, becoming confused and is sometimes disoriented.<br /><br />Reading this is a great way to learn about Alzheimer's and become aware of the symptoms.  It was a bit scary for me to read this and find that my \\"senior moments\\" of forgetting words and names happened to Alice who was diagnosed with Alzheimer's at age 50!  The author actually interviewed people who had early onset of Alzheimer's.  Questions for discussion are included in the back along with an interview by the author.<br /><br />This is a good read and did not drag at all.  Some parts were even humorous.  I highly recommend this book to anyone who enjoys stories about families, relationships or wants to know more about Alzheimer's.  I think it would be a good book for a book club to discuss.

0307272702|5.0|This is basically the quick-read version of \\"Good Calories, Bad Calories.\\" It just demolishes everything we've been taught about food and nutrition all our lives. There is quite a bit of overlap but I've enjoyed reading both Taubes books.    Some of the conclusions are hard to believe, running counter to conventional wisdom and also to our own intuition. But Taubes' survey of the research is exhaustive and his arguments are very tightly woven. Taubes is anything but a quack; he's a highly reputable science writer who has approached this topic as an investigative reporter, not only with exhaustive research of the literature back 200 years, but with hundreds of interviews with experts from all different points of view.     If Taubes is right, and I find it very hard to find fault with this, then the public health establishment from the NIH to the American Heart Association have done just a monumental disservice to Americans by jumping to the scientifically unsupported conclusion that fat in the diet, particularly animal fat, was the source of obesity and heart disease, when the opposite was the case. The research up until the 60s clearly indicated that sugars, starches and cereal grains are what actually causes obesity, NOT animal fat, and the latest research is nailing this conclusively.    Anybody who has experimented with Atkins, South Beach or any low-carb regimen and found it worked for them (and just try to find somebody for whom it didn't work!) will find reassurance in this book as well as \\"Good Calories, Bad Calories.\\"  Many of us quit Atkins simply because we were afraid it was dangerous, and then promptly gained back the weight that we'd lost. This book can make you very confident that you can eat a low carb, high fat diet for the rest of your life without fear and with a high degree of confidence that you will be healthier for it. In fact, a the closest we can get to zero carbs might be the best way to go.    Even Dr. Atkins, perhaps bending to intense pressure, modified his diet over the years to lessen the fat and red meat and emphasize fruits and vegetables more. For most people a heavy dose of vegetables won't do any harm, but Taubes argues persuasively that even the first stage of Atkins -- heavy on meat, eggs and fat, keeping carbs to 10-20 grams a day -- might be just fine as a permanent diet. In fact, it is fruits and vegetables -- particularly sugary fruits and starchy vegetables -- for whom the scientific support is lacking.    I used to tell my daughter that the orange juice, banana and whole wheat waffles breakfast was probably about the same thing chemically as having a candy bar and a soda to start the day. I still believe that after reading Taubes. What I'm surprised about, after reading the book, is how strong the scientific support is for sausage and eggs for breakfast -- as long as you leave out the toast and juice.

B0000028VT|4.0|Mariah's third album came on the heels of two highly successful albums, and a recording of her singing live on MTV's Unplugged in 1992.  Music Box, released in 1993, remains her best-selling album of all time.  I'm not sure that status is all that well-deserved, considering she has done better work since, but it capitalizes on the ballad formula she and Walter Afansieff perfected throughout her first couple of CDs, and she and he execute it very well. Additionally, Civilles and Cole work with Mariah to create two catchy up-tempo numbers.  This being a Mariah album, the vocals are top-notch and there are some beautiful melodies and lyrics on here.  In fact, the more I listen to it, the more I catch the vocal layering that Mariah included as she produced the songs, gorgeous harmonies hidden beneath catchy melodies.        The highlights of this album include the very inspirational Gospel-tinged \\"Anytime You Need a Friend,\\" and \\"Now That I Know.\\" The lyrics are pretty banal, but the melody is very catchy and the beat is classic early 90s uptempo perfection due to her collaboration with Civilles and Cole. Another highlight, with its interesting background is \\"Thinking of You.\\"       As for the love ballads, Mariah has some very beautiful melodies on here, including \\"Music Box,\\" sung very softly (it may be one of the first times she exhibits her \\"whispery\\" vocals), and \\"Just to Hold You Once Again.\\"  Her cover of \\"Without You\\" is breathtaking, and remains the best cover she has ever done.    Aside from the songs I mentioned already, the other couple of tracks on the album are constituted of love ballads, which aren't very remarkable compared to some of Mariah's other ballads.  If you love classic Mariah Carey music, then you will love this album (in the highly unlikely event that you don't already own it).  If you like her newer songs better, then you may or may not like this, as it's pretty heavy on the ballads, and I'd suggest listening to the samples first...

B000002AVF|5.0|A full decade prior to Mimi's emancipation, there was this album.  Daydream contains some of the defining songs of my generation, whether some members of my age group want to admit it or not. Fantasy, Always Be My Baby and One Sweet Day were unavoidable radio staples. (Along with other Carey hits Hero and Dreamlover from her Music Box days).  This was the epitome pop/soft rock radio in the mid-90s, and it was great.    Fantasy, in particular, was my personal favorite single release from the album, and not just because of the genius way she reworked the 1982 Tom Tom Club \\"Genius of Love\\" hook.  The original version is a song I can still listen to and never tire of, but the remix of this particular song, which is not included on this album but is on her #1s album, introduced us to a Mariah we were going to be seeing a lot more of (literally and figuratively, for better or worse) for years to come.  This version of Mariah collaborated with a totally unexpected (gasp!) rap artist (ODB).  A huge fan of hip-hop and rap herself, this was a move she would increasingly make in her songs in every subsequent album, especially once she got around to making the likes of Rainbow and Charmbracelet.  Also, this was a move which other artists would adopt, to create a much more predicted and commonplace pop singer-rap artist collaboration style throughout the late 90s and early 2000s.    Of course, the album has its low point. \\"When I Saw You\\" has so much melisma, I have to skip over it each time. All I can think about when I hear it is that Mariah should pick a note and stick to it, instead of dancing around her notes.  Usually, I love her way of ornamenting her singing, but this song is the one instance where it's too much, even for me, a certified huge MC fan.  It's unfortunate, because if she had just sung it a little differently, it would have been a particularly beautiful song.     Fortunately, though, this is the only song I don't particularly like.  The rest of them are either good or great.  Here is my review of the great ones:    \\"Fantasy\\" such a catchy and upbeat melody, and is sung perfectly and gorgeously.  This is a prime example of the music completely fitting the lyrics, and the execution via the production, vocals, and instrumentation is perfection. \\"Image is a rapture,\\" indeed.      \\"Underneath the Stars\\" is a great sample of Mariah's vocal talent and ability to create gorgeous harmonies with herself as one or more of the backup singers.     \\"Melt Away\\" is classic Mariah and Babyface.  It has the typical '90s synthesized ballad background, but the beat is nice, and the singing is smooth and soothing.  Plus, Mariah dips into her lowest register on this one, which is something she should do a little more often than she does.      \\"I am Free\\" and \\"Looking In\\" I am grouping these together since they represent truly introspective and personal lyrics, and are a nice addition to the collection on the album, between the pop and love ballads.  Mariah did not have a great personal life at the time of this album, and these songs may or may not be a reflection of that.  Whether or not they were written about Mariah's real life, the themes in the songs can be generalized to others' lives so her listener can relate, and in the case of \\"Looking In,\\" sung in a very understated and accessible way.    This album represented only the beginning of a turning point in Mariah's musical styles and her career.  It is a definite must-have for anyone who enjoys pop music and '90s balladry.

B004DWKO8Y|4.0|Much to my (incredibly happy) surprise I happened to notice this title and, yes, Mr Big is (surprisingly) back, after disbanding several years ago, and with the original line up of Martin, Gilbert, Sheehan & Torpey.      Is it a good surprise?  Well, (mostly) yes and no.    Anyone who knows the band knows that they are arguably the most talented rock act currently producing albums (there is no need to bore you with their individual technical prowess) and, on average, they probably get to flex their considerable musical muscle more on this release than any other....but this does not mean it's their best work to date.  In terms of recent releases I would rate this as a significant improvement over the last Paul Gilbert album (Hey Man) but, regrettably, not as good as either of the Ritchie Kotzen albums.    Thankfully, although a Frontiers production, the (sound) quality appears to be above average albeit still shy of previous titles.  In terms of song selection, there is not a (complete) dud on display, and as always for me, I'll like it the more times its played; top tracks are 3, 9, 10 and in particular, 1 & 7.    Glad to see the boys back together, and on this showing hope that it sells enough units to get them doing more; nice to see Paul Gilbert back and, comparatively, he does shred a little more here than usual (perhaps the reason he left in the first place?) but my favourite Mr Big guitar solo is still 'The whole world's gonna know' (from Bump Ahead).    If you like their previous albums then this should have something you'll enjoy.....and when the talent/ability is this good then it should have some merit for anyone with an interest in rock; executed by 4 guys who really know how to play.    Happy listening!

B00377V6J2|5.0|Albert King had a well-earned reputation as a mean, cantankerous old cuss. Watching the smile dance across his face throughout this incredible session is nothing short of remarkable. As is the music. Watch Albert teach himself \\"Pride and Joy\\" by watching Stevie play it, and then watch him make it his own.  Stevie is clearly holding back, toning down his licks out of deference for one of his true mentors. But he sines like only SRV could nonetheless. You can see just how deeply King influenced him, and where he took those licks from there.  (Stevie is also so wasted he can't even remember the words to his own songs. Once or twice the camera catches him sucking air through his nose in a manner that anyone who worked with him would recognize as his post-coke check. That he could play as well as he did during his drug-fueled years made many people thing that drugs were what made him play so fast. What a a blessing we all got when he sobered up and everyone could seethe drugs had been holding him back.)  Note: I have seen some critics who complain that Albert was out of tune for much of this session. Not true. I even ran it through an oscilloscope to check the frequency levels, and Albert was well within harmonic match with Stevie. Must just be some critics who didn't see where the old master was headed from moment to moment.  I miss these guys. I love this DVD/CD set. Buy it.

I've been a fan of Josh Groban since the first time I heard his first album, but Illuminations is seriously something special.
B0015AARJI|5.0|Product: Playstation 3 Dualshock 3 Wireless Controller, by Sony.<br />Rating: 4 1/2 stars<br /><br />LIKES:<br /><br />* QUALITY:  In my experience, when it comes to controllers for the PS3, you pretty much get what you pay for.  Over the years, I've owned a PS1, a PS2, and a PS3, and at various times I've tried 3rd party controllers in an attempt to add multiplayer capability at a more reasonable price ... and unfortunately, I've rarely been happy.  As long as you can afford it, this seems to be the best controller you can get for the PS3 ... it has the best balance of heft, solid construction, good tactile resistance in the buttons and thumbsticks, excellent durability, good vibration feel, good communication range, reasonably fast charge time (2.5 hrs or less), and a long-lived battery.<br /><br />NITS:<br /><br />* Price: Authentic Sony controllers are expensive ... but as mentioned above, you generally get what you pay for.<br /><br />* Charging Cord not included: You'd think that in purchasing a spare/replacement controller that it would come with a charging cord, right ?  Nope.  Sony deliberately omits it, and instead instructs customers to \\"use the one that comes with your PS3\\".  I recently purchased a charging station to eliminate that bottleneck ... which was probably Sony's goal in witholding charging cords from their spare controllers.<br /><br />* Minor design issues:<br />(a) when putting the controller down during active play, there's an occasional tendency for one of the L2/R2 buttons to activate if you're not gentle.  A pair of small support feet on the front of the controller, placed just behind and below those 2 buttons, would solve that.<br />(b) I wish the charging cord connector port was indented slightly, to be self-guiding, to make connections faster and more eyes-free.<br />(c) L3 & R3 are too easily unintentionally activated while using the sticks for movement in many games ... case in point is Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, where you FREQUENTLY end up squatting in mid-combat, while maneuvering during a melee, which is very frustrating.  They need to increase the activation pressure for L3/R3 slightly in order to solve that.<br /><br />Bottom line: I've tried several other brands, and even though the Sony controller is the most expensive among them, it's also the best. 0670022411|5.0|Bought on Audible<br /><br />What I Loved: I am going to warn you that this may be a rambling review.  I adored this book!  I thought it was well written, thought out, and presented.  I think the author (or whoever wrote the blurb) did themselves a HUGE disservice comparing it to Twilight because it is nothing like that angsty series.  This is not full of love triangles, weak leading ladies, or teenagers.  This book is full of action, adventure, history, love (both of the main characters and their family/friends), intrigue, and mystery.  The leading lady Diana is a wonderful example of someone who has spent most of her life hiding from who she is and developing a life outside of it.  She is Harvard educated, a brilliant scholar, and leading a relatively normal life till her magic makes her understand that she can't just turn her back on being witch.  This unfolds slowly through most the book and what I liked was watching the stages.  Yes, they unfolded over a short amount of time (3 weeks or so) but each one was deliberate.  Much like her falling in love with Matthew, a fellow scholar but also a Vampire.  In the world in which Ms. Harkness created, the 3 non-human species are not supposed to mix.  This book, which is the first in the trilogy, introduces you to this world, gives you a starting glimpse into the troubles to come, and does an excellent job of drawing you in and keeping you interested.<br /><br />What I Liked:  Attention to detail both large and small.  The landscape, people, and world were brilliantly described and introduced.<br /><br />Complaints:  The \\"I Love You\\" does get bit repetitive between Matthew and Diana but that is just a personal preference that I know they are going to say before parting.  I don't actually have to read it.<br /><br />Audio Specific Review:  EXCELLENT Narration by Jennifer Ikeda.  She managed to capture the essence of every character (and there quite a few) very well.  My favorite was Izabo, her presentation of that character was spot on and fun!<br /><br />Why I Gave it a 5  (and kind of why you would not necessarily): I really enjoy long, sweeping tales when they are done right with lots of detail, strong story, and likable characters.  I grew up reading books like The North and The South, The Westward Ho Series,  and later they were joined by The Stand and Outlander.  These type of books require time, commitment, and an understanding the action will not always be fast and furious.  This book was excellent in the pacing, storytelling, and character building.  I was never bored and always wanted to know what happened next.  I was sad when the book ended and I didn't have the 2nd one there ready to go.<br /><br />Who I would recommend it too:  This is tough!  This isn't a PNR (though it does have a love story) and it isn't a Thriller/Mystery (though it does have both elements in it).  This is however a very well written book that I think fans of books like The Outlander series may enjoy.  This isn't going to be for everyone (aka the reason I have seen reviews from 2 to 5) but those that love it are going to be passionate about it!<br /><br />Author Website: [...]I Gave it a 5  (and kind of why you would not necessarily): I really enjoy long, sweeping tales when they are done right with lots of detail, strong story, and likable characters. 0439023521|1.0|How does the experience of reading Hunger Games compare with an equivalent number of hours at the joystick playing Mortal Kombat?  Well in Mortal Konbat, the plot twists are likely more probable, the internal logic more consistent, and the underlying moral value somewhat more lofty.  At least the online gamer slaughters relentless hoards of mutants or beefy professional mercenaries.  He is not asked to participate in the killing of unarmed innocents that he has come to like, and then fault them for their deaths.  At least one among the \\"career tributes\\" (game-victims) is a psychopath.  This is Cato.  He says of our heroine \\"When we find her, I get to kill her in my own way, and no one interferes.\\"  We are invited to hate Cato and to celebrate his death.  This is a most unfair device it seems to me for it shifts blame for the game's atrocities to one of its victims.  Cato by the way is killed finally by a pack of zombie dogs that are the reincarnated children who have been murdered earlier in the game.         Let me say it differently.  If killing Cato by calling up murdered children from the dead and reincarnating them as a pack of zombie dogs is a satisfactory resolution to the novel's central conflicts and themes, then what are the novel's central conflicts and themes?  What is the crime that justifies--in moral terms--such terrible retribution?  There is none because the dogs have no judgment.  The dog pack is not an arrow aimed with some clear intent; it is a bomb set off in a crowd.  The dogs would have killed Katniss just as quickly as they did Kato.  It's simply random and mindless murder without purpose.         Among the other dead, one is a young girl who's been nicknamed Foxface.  Any girl called Foxface by other girls deserves to die, does she not?  No one need cry for her.  Or so Collins would have it.  Here's the female tribute from District 1 before the slaughter: \\"With that flowing blonde hair, emerald green eyes, her body tall and lush, she'ssexy all the way.\\"  Oh, she's wearing a see-though gown by the way.  We have several of these titillating beauty-contest moments in the book that are presented without any sense of irony or cynicism.         So let's be clear.  Suppose you are presented with two works of imaginative art--both artists being adults.  The first is a pen and ink drawing of two children engaged in a pornographic act.  The second is a passage from a novel that graphically describes one child killing another.  Sensing where I'm headed with this, you might stop me with the complaint, \\"But that's unfair.  The passage is taken out of context.  The killing takes place in a work of fiction with overall artistic value.\\"  But does it?  The charge I'm so clumsily making is that the tone of meritorious futuristic or fantasy fiction is a masquerade that makes the pornography of death palatable.         The troublesome question is then, is Collins herself the faceless Gamemaker of the novel?  It seems so.  It is she and she alone who designs and inflicts the injustices and the abuses and the deaths of children simply for the entertainment those grim outcomes provide.  Collins seems a statistic bully.

This book set me up for life.)<br /><br />I remember turning the final page, past Grover's final adorable plea, to discover...<br /><br />What, you think I'm going to TELL you?! Think again - read this book to your kids or better yet, let them read it for themselves. Let them discover the nature of fear and the strength in conquering it, the fun of having a character in a book interact with them directly.<br /><br />They'll remember it for the rest of their lives.

The Tributes are then sent into an arena to fight to the death. The reason they do this is because 75 years ago the Districts had a rebellion against the Capitol. The Hunger Games is basically the Capitol's way of saying \\"We're still bigger and stronger than you\\".      What does Katniss do in the book? Good question. I will answer this after I tell you SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!!!! Katniss's sister gets her name drawn and she instantly volunteers to go up instead. Everyone is so stunned at the thought of it that no-one says a word. Anyone from District 12 basically knows that going into the Games is a certain death sentence. 0070511136|2.0|SPIN Selling was the first book I read on sales where I didn't feel like I had to take a shower afterwards. Neil Rackham is the grandfather of making sales a respectable profession.    He helped a lot of salespeople out of the presentation ppt trap.    The problem was that he did this through questions. Although questions can work, I just feel stories are better. Here's why:    Buyers hate feeling manipulated and asking questions can feel like an interrogation painting the Buyer into a corner.    Also, salespeople can get lost in a sea of questions and lose sight of the story they are trying to sell.    Isn't it just easier to provide the Salesperson with the right message delivered through mini-stories to help the Buyer discover that the status quo is no longer acceptable. These stories work because they present a scenario that allows Buyers to develop awareness through their own sense of discovery. Buyers trust this discovery because they made it and they begin to trust the Story Seller for telling it. When the Buyer can picture the issues  in the real world scenario, it helps them see how the results may apply to them and they start to make sense- they gain insight. Stories transport the Buyer from the role of critic into the role of participant.    In short, Stories allow the Buyer to take your offering for a virtual mental test drive: Could you ask for more?    I feel that it's easier to help the Buyer decide to change through the use of use 5-20 mini-stories followed by a few basic qualification questions instead of 50-250 discovery questions.    Indeed, stories are easier to remember, faster to execute and more natural to deliver. This is nothing new, just look at the Bible, it's all about stories. Stories are how we make sense of the world. We know how to tell stories; we just have to make sure we tell the right ones. at InsightDemand
